The Authenticity of the Book of Mormon The authenticity of the Book of Mormon constitutes our most important consideration of the work. Announcing to the. World the message of a departed people, written by way of commandment, and by the spirit of prophecy and revelation, this book is entitled to the most thorough and impartial examination. The Latter-day Saints base their belief in the authenticity of the book on the following proofs which will be discussed: 1. The Nephite and the Jewish scriptures are found to agree in matters of tradition, history, doctrine, and prophecy which the separate records treat. In a careful comparison of the prophecies of the Bible with corresponding predictions contained in the Book of Mormon, each of the records is corroborative of the other. 2. Ancient prophecy has been literally fulfilled in the coming forth of the Book of Mormon. Enoch (Pearl of Great Price, Moses 7:59- 62), David (Psalms 85:11), Isaiah (Isaiah 45:8), and Ezekiel (Ezekiel 37), as well as other prophets knew and prophecied of the book. Ezekiel 37:15-17, reads: "The word of the Lord came unto me, saying, Moreover, thou son of man, take thee one stick, and write upon it, For Judah, and for the children of Israel his companions [signifying the Bible]: then take another stick, and write upon it, For Joseph, the stick of Ephraim, and for all the house of Israel his companions [signifying the Book of Mormon]: And join them one to another into one stick; and they shall become one in thine hand." 3. The internal consistency of the Book of Mormon sustains belief in Page 57 its divine origin. The parts bear evidence of having been written at different times and under widely varying conditions. The book maintains consistency throughout; no contradictions, no disagreements have been pointed out. 4. Among the most conclusive proofs of the authenticity of the book is that furnished by the demonstrated truth of its contained prophecies. The predictions contained within the Book of Mormon may be classed as (a) prophecies relating to the time covered by the book itself, the fulfillment of which is recorded therein; and (b) prophecies relative to times beyond the limits of the history chronicled in the book. Prophecies of the first class named are of minor value as proof of the authenticity of the work; nevertheless, to the conscientious reader the genuineness of the book will be made apparent in the literal realization of the numerous and varied predictions relating to the fate, then future, of the people whose history is given in the record. Prophecies of the second class are numerous and explicit. Many of them have special reference to this last dispensationthe Dispensation of the Fullness of Times. Among the most remarkable Book of Mormon predictions incident to the last dispensation are those that relate to its own coming forth and the effect of its publication amongst mankind. Joseph's great prophetic utterance is to be found in part in II Nephi 3:11-13. The literal fulfillment of this prophecy in the bringing forth of the Book of Mormon through Joseph Smith is well evidenced. That the new scriptures would be rejected by the Gentiles was known by Nephi, who recorded this: "A Bible! A Bible! We have got a Bible, and there cannot be any more Bible." (II Nephi 29:3; read the entire chapter.) 5. The archeology and ethnology of the Western Continent contribute some corroborative evidence in support of the Book of Mormon. Among the most significant of the discoveries respecting the aboriginal inhabitants of the land, are the following: (a) that America was peopled in very ancient times, probably soon after the building of the Tower of Babel; (b) that the continent has been successfully occupied by different peoples, at least by two classes, or so-called races, at widely separated periods; (c) that the aboriginal inhabitants came from the East, probably from Asia, and that the latter occupants, or those of the second period, were closely allied to, if not identified with, the Israelites; (d) that the existing native races of America form a common stock. It is very apparent that each of these discoveries is fully sustained by the Book of Mormon record. Let not the reader of the Book of Mormon content himself with such evidences as have been cited concerning the authenticity of this reputed scripture. There is promised a surer and more effectual means of ascertaining the truth or falsity of this volume. Like other scriptures, the Book of Mormon is to be comprehended through the spirit of the scripture, and this is obtainable only as a gift from God. But this gift is promised unto all who shall seek it. Then to all let us commend the counsel of the last writer in the volume, Moroni, solitary scribe who
sealed the book: "And when ye shall receive these things, I would exhort you that ye would ask God, the Eternal Father, in the name of Christ, if these things are not true; and if ye shall ask with a sincere heart, with
59
real intent, having faith in Christ, he will manifest the truth of it unto you, by the power of the Holy Ghost. And by the power of the Holy Ghost ye may know the truth of all things." (Moroni 10:4-5)
LESSON PLAN
Lesson Aim: To prove the authenticity of the Book of Mormon
Suggested Material Outline
I. Proofs of the authenticity of the Book of Mormon A. Agreement of the Bible and the Book of Mormon
1. Records agree in matters of tradition, history, doctrine and prophecy (See Appendix 14:5) B. Prophecies concerning the Book of Mormon
2. Ezekiel's vision most significant (Ezekiel 37)
3. Isaiah's prediction literally fulfilled (Isaiah 29:11-12) C. Internal construction of the Book of Mormon This concerns the doctrinal unity of the book, its consistency of language, its general harmony and Joseph Smith's inability to compose such a work without divine help. D. Book of Mormon predictions
4. Prophecies fulfilled in the Book of Mormon
5. Future prophecies not yet fulfilled (See II Nephi 3:11-13; II Nephi 29 E. Archaeology of the Western Continent
6. Value of external evidence Sometimes we are inclined to lay too much stress on external evidence, as if it were conclusive, whereas it only shows a tendency in the direction of the truth of personal testimony.
7. Evidence of American antiquities a. Civilization here before discovery of America by Columbus b. This civilization comparable to that which existed in the Old World c. Monuments are found where Book of Mormon requires them to be d. Evidences of successive civilizations in ancient America F. The classes of American aborigines (1.) Archaic (2.) Toltec-Mayan (3.) Aztec
Suggested Method Outline
I. It is suggested that class members who are capable and who do research well, be assigned, at least a month in advance of presentation, the five major sections of this lesson outline. In making such assignments, it is suggested that the class leader bear in mind the following procedure: A. Enough time should be spent with the class member assigned the task to make the assignment very clear. If necessary, the assignment should be written out by the class leader, and then the member should be given time to ask questions concerning her assignment. B. Class leaders should make the time limit explicit. This is very important if the lesson is fully covered in the time allotted. C. Class leaders should be responsible for seeing that material for use in the preparation of assignments is available. D. Some follow-through on the assignment should be made by the class leader to check on the progress of each assignment, and this should be done before the actual day of presentation. II. Class leaders should allow themselves time to summarize the major points of the lesson in order to make a unified whole and to increase learning. Part of this summary could be gathered from the class by skillful questioning. (Consult any book on teaching methods for help on how to formulate questions. If a blackboard is available, it would be helpful to list thereon the major points covered in the lesson.)
References Roberts, B. H., A Comprehensive History of the Church, Vol. I. Talmage, James E., Sunday Night Talks. Thompson, E. H., People of the Serpent. Talmage, James E., Articles of Faith, "Appendix" 15, Notes Relating to Chap. 15

Visiting Teachers Messages to the Home
Lesson 7 Care of the Body as an Expression of Faith (Tuesday, April 6, 1943)
LATTER-DAY SAINTS attach great importance to the proper care of the body. No one can attain his highest usefulness, happiness, or intelligence, who injures his body by improper living. In the Doctrine and Covenants there are many revelations regarding the human body and its importance as an instrument of the mind. "The spirit and the body," we are informed, "are the soul of man." (Section 88:15) And in another place we read that the spirit manifests itself through the body. Therefore, the physical condition of the body either facilitates or hampers expression of the spirit. Such things as food, clothing, proper housing and living conditions
are "given to strengthen the body and enliven the soul." (Doctrine and Covenants 59:19) Section 88:124 gives instructions for the maintenance of the body. "Cease to be idle; cease to be unclean;... Cease to sleep longer than is needful; retire to thy bed early, that ye may not be weary; arise early, that your bodies and your minds may be invigorated." Then there is the Word of Wisdom (Section 89), which offers specific instructions: tobacco, "strong or hot drinks," excessive meat eating are "not good for man;" while fruit in the season thereof is good for the use of man, and wheat is specially "for man." Obedience to these teachings is attended by certain blessings. There are also revelations in the Doctrine and Covenants which indicate that the care of the body is a religious duty. The attitude of the mind and the emotions one cultivates have an effect on the health of the body. This fact was enunciated by Jesus and it
*Discourses of Brigham Young, page 283, makes clear that President Brigham Young regarded tea and coffee among the hot drinks referred to in Doctrine and Covenants, Section 89.
61
finds ample justification, if any is needed, in what we know from the study of the body. Christ assures us that fear, anger, hate, with kindred emotions, are a source of injury. He puts it theologically: "Thou shalt not be angry with thy brother." But science gives us the reason. Says Herbert Spencer, in his Data of Ethics: "From biology we learn that no act should be committed or thought entertained which weakens the body, for thereby the human being is rendered unfit for the duties of life." Obedience to the laws of health, both those revealed through religion and those discovered by man in his search for truth, express our faith in the teachings of the Church so far as concerns the sanctity of the body.
Discussion
1. What should be the attitude of all citizens toward community health?
2. In what ways can women cooperate with the civil authorities in maintaining healthy conditions in the community?
3. Discuss Doctrine and Covenants 88:124, with regard to proper rest; also Gospel Doctrine by Joseph F. Smith, page 461.
4. What are the physical effects of fear, anger, hate?
5. What are the blessings promised those who obey the Word of Wisdom?

Work-and-Business New-fashioned Thrift
Lesson 6 Clean Things Last Longer (For optional use on Tuesday, March 9, 1943)
NOT only is "cleanliness next to Godliness," but it is also economical. It is easier to keep clean than to make clean. Dirt wears things out, whether they be fabric, wood, plaster, leather, or fur. Good materials are entitled to good care. Waiting until they are very dirty before cleaning them means added rubbing and scrubbing that wears things out as much as does the dirt that is ground into them in the first place. While it is necessary to keep things clean to conserve them, it is also necessary in cleaning them to use the process best suited to the material or fabric involved. Some fabrics take kindly to mild soap and water, while others require dry-cleaning agents. The difficulty today is in knowing the material with which one is dealing. Rayon, the versatile fiber, is woven into a variety of fabrics; and since these fabrics are so extensively used, it is important to have a knowledge of their care. Some rayon fibers lose their strength when wet; others are dissolved when cleaning agents are used; and some are melted by the use of too much heat. The cleaning of any material containing rayon fiber depends on the nature of the weave as much as the fiber itself. Rough or creped surfaces should usually be dry cleaned. If material can be washed, the kind of soap, the temperature of the water used, the handling while wet, and the length of time given for drying are important items to remember. All fabrics of rayon, silk, and wool, whether used for clothing, upholstering, curtains, draperies, or rugs, require a mild soap, luke-warm water, little handling with no harsh rubbing or wringing. A long time is required for properly drying all of these fabrics except pure silk, which dries quickly. The amount of soap required will depend upon the harshness of the water, and whether or not a softening agent is used. Trisodium phosphate is a good detergent. Sheer fabrics when washed should be rolled in a soft absorbent cloth, such as a turkish towel, to absorb the excessive moisture, and they should be ironed with a warm iron while damp. Some fabrics, because of fineness, construction, or color, respond best to dry cleaning, and if done at home, extreme care should be taken in the handling of articles and in the selection of the cleaning agent to be used. Whether laundering or dry-cleaning method is used, stains should be removed from the article before the whole article is cleaned. The proper time to remove stain is when it is fresh. Air, heat, and water may change the character of the stain and make it difficult to remove, if it can be removed at all. It is much easier to remove a stain without injury to the fabric if the kind of stain is known. Most ordinary stains on tub-fast, washable materials, such as cotton or linen, can be removed with warm water; or in case of fruit stain, boiling water poured from a height. Stubborn stains, like ink, require special treatment.* Clothing and fabric articles that can be handled easily should be brushed often and regularly. Dust and dirt work into the meshes of the weave and cut the threads. The best time to brush clothing is immediately after wearing. Underwear and stockings should be washed often; fibers deteriorate with perspiration and body acids. In most homes, rugs and upholstery usually get a bigger share of the wear than other articles. To avoid some of this wear, they should have a quick daily cleaning, rather than to allow dust and dirt to work into the pile. A more thorough cleaning should be given weekly. The best cleaning implements to use are a vacuum cleaner and a carpet sweeper. Sweeping with a broom, especially against the pile, will further embed the dirt, and may tear or damage the soft, wool nap. Greasy spots and soil cause dirt to stick, which, in turn, dulls the colors. A good nonflammable cleansing fluid will brighten colors and remove spots. Some kinds of rugs and upholstery can be shampooed with safety if a thick jelly-like suds is made of neutral soap and applied with a brush using a circular motion. The lather should be scraped off with a dull broad knife, and then wiped off with a damp, clean cloth wrung out of clean warm water. This process should be repeated as many times as is necessary to remove all soap and soil. As little water as possible should be used. Articles should be allowed to dry thoroughly before being used. A thorough cleaning occasionally by an expert will prolong the life of such furnishings. Hard shaking of small rugs breaks the backing and unravels the ends or fringe. A rug laid on a smooth surface or over a pad not only wears longer but is easier to keep clean. If slip covers are used, they should be removed often enough for cleanliness and to make sure that moths do not lurk beneath them to feast on the precious fabrics of the davenport or chairs. Tablecloths, luncheon cloths, and
*See America's Housekeeping Book, Chapter 25, p. 323.
napkins are made of various kinds of fabrics, such as cotton, linen, rayon, silk, and Cellophane. Linen and cotton, if white, can stand hot water; if colored, warm water should be used in washing. They should be washed quickly, rinsed thoroughly and, if white, dried in sun; if colored, they should be dried in the shade. Grass linen is stiff and should be handled carefully so as not to break the threads. Cotton and linen require a hotter iron in pressing than do other fabrics. Mats made entirely of Cellophane only need to be wiped with a damp cloth to clean. A bit of starch in the rinsing water will give cotton a gloss when ironed and keep it clean longer. Never use starch for other materials, especially linen. If ironed linens are rolled on a pasteboard or paper roll rather than folded, they keep fresh, clean, and wear longer. The folds in larger cloths should be changed occasionally to prevent wear along the line of the fold. Bedding should have its share of care. A clean, soft, but firm mattress, fluffy clean blankets, and clean sheets are inviting and help one to rest well. Soiled bedding is not nearly so warm as clean bedding. Regular airing and sunning of the mattress will keep it fluffy. A mattress should have a cover that fits snugly and that can be removed for washing. The rules for washing table linen apply also to bed linen. Over-washing of woolen blankets mats the
63
nap and causes harshness and shrinkage. Blankets will be fluffy and soft if dried out-of-doors on a mild, breezy day. Sheets hung straight and smooth on the line, dried, and then carefully removed and folded, need
64
not be ironed other than to press the hems. Occasionally the wood of furniture needs a thorough cleaning with thick soap suds to remove the grime and smoke that collect and dull the beautiful surfaces. In modern heated homes, furniture gets too dry, which sometimes causes it to crack and come apart. If washed carefully, a small part at a time, without much water, wiped thoroughly dry with a soft cloth, and polished with a good furniture polish rubbed with the grain of the wood, the wood of most furniture will look like new, and the little bit of water used will help restore the moisture drawn out by overheated houses. Floors often become loose and squeak from the same cause. Floor surfaces should be kept clean, and the finish, whether oil, wax, paint, or varnish, should be well applied. This prevents the floor from wearing, whether it be wood, linoleum or tile, and is particularly important where floors receive great
wear. Too frequent and too generous use of soap and water has a tendency to deteriorate rather than preserve some finishes. Each kind should have its own treatment. Paste, liquid or self-polishing wax are sometimes used too generously. When there is an accumulation of this wax, it should be removed; the floor should be thoroughly cleaned and new wax applied. Painted walls may be cleaned with a mild soap and water, or a water softener or solvent and water. They should be wiped well after washing. Long even strokes should be used when wallpaper and calcimine are cleaned with the dough-like preparations now on the market. Rubbing back and forth makes streaks and embeds the dirt in the paper. The main point to remember in cleaning all materials and articles is that they should not become too soiled.
NOTE: America's Housekeeping Book, sections one, two, and three, pp. 131-335, contains a wealth of material on this subject.

Literature The Bible as Literature
Lesson 7 Some of the Great Personalities in the Bible (Tuesday, April 20, 1943)
Objective: To remind us of some of the great characters in the Bible and help us to appreciate the qualities which made them great and to sense their influence upon our own lives.
Lesson Topics
1. Introduction
2. Abraham
3. Moses
4. Eve
Introduction
Carlyle says: "There are great personalities who march through history with voices like clarion trumpets and something like glittering swords in their hands.... Contact with them warms and kindles the mind." By association with superior personalities, either in the flesh or through the medium of literature, we take on some of their greatness. Many people feel that the Bible has more eminent characters than any other book of literature. This is one of its claims to greatness. Frank S. Mead draws attention to this fact in his book 250 Bible Biographies. Henry T. Sell includes only twenty-one men in his Studies of Great Bible Characters, but his selection point definitely to outstanding men who have given us ideal and moral uplift by the ideals, struggles, and achievements of their own lives. He writes of Abraham, the man who dared to trust God; of Isaac, who accepted the challenge of obedience; of Joseph, the dreamer whose dreams came true; of Moses, the leader and law-giver of a nation; of Joshua, the courageous man with a hard task; of Saul, the man who abused his opportunities; of David, the self-conqueror who became king; of Job, the man of undeserved suffering; of Isaiah, the world prophet and statesman; of Daniel, the man who made advantage out of disadvantage; of Luke, the man who broadcasted the Gospel's good news; of Paul, the man who bettered city conditions; and many others. Mr. Sell describes his characters as men who were "the outstanding and strategic leaders in their own times, the men who molded the thought and directed the action of the ages
65
in which they lived, but who today are even more influential, for they realized, were profoundly influenced by, and worked enthusiastically for ideals and principles which still lead us on." They had their faults and made mistakes, for they were very human; but above every other desire, they had that of bringing the kingdom of God on earththis was their glory. We can learn from them today by seeing how they met their problems and worked them out. Mr. Sell says, "They were hardy adventurers on the sea of life who, despite violent storms, came safely to port with rich cargoes. To examine how they did this will richly repay our study, for in their successes they rise above their nationality and every age." Though Mr. Mead gives no more than his regular two or three hundred words to his thumb-nail sketch of Jesus, and Mr. Sell does not include Him at all, we know that both would give him first place among Biblical characters. Hundreds of books have been written upon His life and mission. Most of them have recognized His divinity, though a few have attempted to understand him as a man alone. Of such writers, Harry Emerson Fosdick says in The Modern Uses of the Bible, p. 272: "Of all foolish things, I think nothing is more foolish than, looking back over our race's history and discerning amid its tragedy and struggles this outstanding figure spiritually supreme, to minimize him, to tone down our thought of him, to reduce him so that we can be like him. Rather let us exalt him! If God be not in Jesus, God is not anywhere. The best hope of mankind is that God is in him and may flow down through all the secret runnels of the race." So important is the personality of Jesus that an entire lesson needs to be devoted to him. In this lesson we shall consider a few of the other Bible characters.
Abraham
That Abraham believed in God and trusted Him to the highest degree is seen in the sacrifice of Isaac. He probably felt as parents do today who sacrifice their sons for the good of their country. There is something of an analogy, too, in the willingness of parents in our Church to send their sons and daughters into strange lands to preach the Gospel. Often they realize that dangers will beset them, but they are proud to give them to the service of our Lord. Our Heavenly Father himself set the divine example, for "He so loved the world that he gave His only begotten Son." Of Abraham, William L. Phelps says, "Unlike most of the Old Testament heroes, hardly anything evil can be charged against him. He was spiritual-minded. He was obedient to the divine voice, and his unfaltering trust in God was rewarded." Mr. Sell says that Abraham stands out as a commanding figure; that he had the traits of character that make great leaders; that he had daring and splendid executive ability; that he was large-hearted and far-sighted and would have made an eminent statesman or victorious general had the opportunity come. Abraham was the founder of the Israelitish nation; his name is revered by Christians, Jews, and Mohammedans; he is still blessing mankind by making it easier for them to worship and love God and by showing them how to live uprightly under trying circumstances.
Moses
Moses was another genius, a leader at a critical period of Israelitish history. He was a lawgiver and a statesman; a guide to the Chosen People in Egypt and in the wilderness. Books have been written about Moses. Lectures have characterized him as the great Hebrew statesman. A scientist, calling him "Moses, the physician," has praised his advanced ideas concerning cleanliness and segregation of disease. He is depicted as gentle in manners, modest, and above all self-controlled, courageous, and strong. He has been classed as the "meekest" of menthe finest tribute to soldiers and kings. "The meek shall inherit the earth" suggests that there is no strength like the strength of meekness. Phelps says, "That Moses was the meekest man in ancient history, is the best thing said about him." The story of Moses' birth and concealment in the rushes is like the plot of a modern novel or movie. When Pharaoh's daughter named him, she did better than she knew, for Moses meant "drawer out," and he drew the Children of Israel out of slavery. His first act of which we have record was indicative of his later career as a deliverer. He saw an Egyptian beating a Hebrew, and he killed the Egyptian, though perhaps he knew he would be condemned by his own people, taunted and insulted, and branded as a murderer. Moses' best preparation for his
later leadership came to him unconsciously while he kept the flocks of his father-in-law. The quiet, meditative life of the desert shepherd brought him in close communion with God, who gave him the sign of the burning bush to make him aware of his call to leadership. To convince his people that he had been divinely called, Moses was permitted to do a number of impressive miracles, such as turning his rod into a snake, making his hand leprous, and then well and whole again. Later miracles, of course, were much more spectacular, when he was called to compete with the magicians of the king who were trying to subdue the Israelites. The story of the Ten Plagues has been called "a tragedy in ten acts ending with a climax." This story and other incidents in the life of this great man are well known. We need here, perhaps, only to remind ourselves that though he was born in slavery, he stands out as one of the greatest figures in the history of mankind, his chief accomplishment being that he took a people who had been in the worst type of slavery the world has ever known, and made it into a great nation with as pure moral and spiritual ideals as the world has ever known. Great characters in the Bible are not confined to men. Mr. Mead includes many women among his biographies, and Willard Done, of our own Church, wrote a little book entitled Women of the Bible. Among interesting fictional books based on Biblical characters is Mary Borden's Mary of Nazareth. In this lesson we shall consider briefly but one of the great women in the Bible.
67
Eve
Little has been written about Eve, and there is little in the scriptures directly concerning her. Yet she holds a unique position in being the first woman in the world. That Eve had the womanly qualities that have preserved for her daughters their place in the shrine of men's hearts through all succeeding ages is evidenced by Adam's first recorded utterances about her and his willingness to share her fall. He said: "Therefore shall a man leave his father and his mother and shall cleave unto his wife: they shall be one flesh." (Genesis 2:24) Adam could have refused to partake of the forbidden fruit. He knew well the painful consequences. Condemned for her sin, Eve has been harshly called weak; she has been reproached as the agent through whom mankind fell. She doubtless was weak and failed to discriminate between vastly different values. But let us consider some of her other characteristics. She was highly sensitive to the beauties and glories in the Garden of Eden. She longed for the gifts her tempter promisedwisdom and understanding equal to that of the gods. These would add to her power to enjoy beauty. The serpent, we must remember, had also promised that she would not die. Doubtless, too, she wanted Adam to possess something of inestimable valuethe wisdom of the gods. We must remember that Eve had had no experience. She had not learned, as most of us have to learn, that disobedience brings punishment. The promise that she would know good from evil, that she would see as God, that she would not dieall these constituted so great a temptation that she could not resist it. But to understand the mature woman it is necessary to follow Eve's career outside the Garden of Eden. As Willard Done says: "The first family was founded and the first real home established when Eve exclaimed in triumph at the birth of Cain, 'I have gotten a man from the Lord!' For the first time in the world the miracle of human birth had been experienced; and Eve was the first to know all the pain and sorrow and joy and triumph it entailed.... The first mother had looked with joy on her first born. The crowning triumph of her life had come, worth the sacrifice even of such a place as Eden. "As Eve was the first to know the experience of human birth, so she was the first mother to endure the sorrow of death, and that in its most terrible form, the murder of one of her sons by the other. It seems to have been her lot to sound all the depths and reach all the heights of woman's experience, "as if she had been destined to be an exemplar to her descendants by passing through all the joys, sorrows, glories, and humiliations that woman can know. Into her life were crowded the events which fulfilled the pronouncement following the fall.... To lose her first two sons, one by violent death and the other by the punishment of exile, was to sound the lowest depths of grief and humiliation. It is difficult to conceive of a greater sorrow. In her endurance of this bitterness, Eve proved herself again the heroine we have always thought her to be. And as so often happens in our griefs, the great loss was made up to her. Another son, Seth, was given her to fill, in part, the places left vacant by the murder of Abel and the exile of Cain. "And so Eve fought her fight and filled her place as the first wife and mother.... To have been the first woman, realizing in her long and eventful life all the experiences of womanhood and earning all its rewards, was to accomplish in its fullness the mission of her sex. No greater appreciation of Eve or higher praise for her work can be given." We cannot help wondering if Eve ever had the joy of foreseeing that through a far-off descendant would come one to redeem the world. That vision, could she have foreseen the coming of Christ from her posterity, would have been a comfort and support to her through the years. Mary, the mother of Jesus, will be presented in the next lesson.
Study Helps
1. Contrast the character of Moses with that of Aaron.
2. Discuss the influence of the Ten Commandments (Exodus 20:3-17) upon history. How do they affect our lives today?
3. Who are your five favorite Biblical heroes? Why?
4. What women characters besides Eve and Mary seem particularly important to you? Why?
5. Have some member read excerpts from Ruth and Esther; the Song of Deborah, or some similar passages from the Bible.
6. "Jephthah's Daughter", or "Hagar," by N. C. Willis might be given as a dramatic reading.
References *Phelps, W. L., Human Nature in the Bible.
Fosdick, Harry E., The Modern Use of the Bible. Sell, H. T., Studies of Great Bible Characters. Mead, Frank S., Bible Biographies. *Done, Willard, Women of the Bible. Taylor, William N., Ruth and Esther.
, p. 548; July 1932, p. 390. "Paradise Lost," by Milton.
Note: Books marked with asterisk (*) are now out of print, but those who have access to these books will find them helpful.
Social Science What "America" Means
Lesson 7 Growth of Political Parties in America (Tuesday, April 27, 1943)
"He serves his party best, who serves his country best." Rutherford B. Hayes
"A thing to be remembered by every man who wishes to make his influence felt for good in our politics is that he must act purely as an American.... If we wish to do good work for our country, we must be unselfish, disinterested, sincerely desirous of the well-being of the commonwealth, and capable of a devoted adherence to a lofty ideal." Theodore Roosevelt
WHEN George Washington was elected President of the United States in 1789, there were no political parties. At the beginning of the Revolutionary War, the people had divided into Whigs and Tories, or Patriots and Loyalists, but the result of the war had been final, and during the discussion and ratification of the Constitution of the United States, there had been Federalists and Anti-Federalists; the adoption of the Constitution, however, seemed to end the existence of the latter. Nevertheless, there were groups and cleavages from which parties would arise in time. There were the frontier and the settled states along the Atlantic seaboard; the rich and the poor; the agricultural and commercial classes; those who believed in a strong central government and those who stood for the fullest possible sovereignty of the different states; those who believed that the Constitution should be interpreted as strictly as possible and those who wished to give its clauses the widest possible interpretation. But on April 30, 1789, when the inauguration of Washington occurred, there were no party organizations. Washington thus had a clear field from which to make his appointments, and he believed that the presidency should not be a partisan office. When President Washington organized his cabinet, among the prominent men that he called to office were Thomas Jefferson and Alexander Hamilton, the former becoming Secretary of State and the latter, Secretary of the Treasury. In the different political theories of these two men, one discovers the cleavages from which our two great modern political partiesRepublican and Democratarose. No two men could have been more different, both in character and in views as to what government should be in the newly organized nation. Hamilton was born in the West Indies and as a young boy landed in New York with his fortune to make. He studied law and married into a wealthy New York family and became a leading figure in the state. He had a brilliant mind and an attractive personality. Jefferson was born on the frontier in Virginia. While Hamilton lived among the moneyed classes of New York, Jefferson was influenced by the people of the country life. He had complete faith in the wisdom of what we call "the common man." Hamilton believed in a strong central government, while Jefferson believed that government should be left to the people within their respective states as far as possible. Hamilton stood for a high protective tariff, a tax to protect the manufacturing industries of America. Jefferson believed that the tax or tariff on foreign goods made articles more expensive, and he radically opposed any tax on foreign goods. One can readily see that three great problems soon confronted the American people. They were: (1) Shall negro slavery be eliminated? (2) Shall a high protective tariff be maintained on imported goods? (3) Do the individual states have rights and powers over and above those granted by the Federal Government? Along these lines the American people took sides, and were grouped principally in two political camps, which eventually emerged into our major parties of today. The political parties of our national history grew out of the devergent geographical conditions of the country, for these conditions were conducive of conflicting economic or industrial interests. Cold winters and poor rock soil made most of the area of New England unsuited to extensive agriculture, but the abundant water power, proximity to the raw products of the West, and the skilled labor which that section always had, gave it extensive commercial and industrial advantages. After the War of 1812, aided by a high protective tariff, the industrial development of New England was rapid.. On the other hand, geographical conditions in the South were most favorable to the development of agticulture. The Southern people always complained that the tariff laws of the Government not only restricted trade in the South, but increased the price of manufactured goods. Then, too, the cotton indus-. Try of the Southern States fostered the growth of negro slavery, an institution which the Northern States came to abhor. Each section, therefore, was eager for political power, and during the years from 1780, when our Government was organized, down to the Civil War (1861- 1865), great statesmen lived to fight courageously for the political ideals which they held to be right. Such men were Daniel Webster, John C. Calhoun, Henry Clay, Andrew Jackson, Abraham Lincoln, Stephen A. Douglas, Jefferson Davis, and many others. It has been said that "the history of political parties in America  LESSON DEPARTMENT is a history of great statesmen, who though differing with their colleagues stood' shoulder to shoulder in demanding that they be in very truth Americans." BRIEF survey will help the reader to understand the history of the two major parties in our political development. From Thomas Jefferson's administration (1801-9) to 1825, the Democratic-Republicans were in power. 'They followed pretty much the policies of Jefferson. In 1825, this party dropped the name Republican, and took the name of Jacksonian Democrats, after Andrew Jackson. A new party was formed to oppose Jackson, which in 1830 took the name of Whigs. From 1830 to 1850, when slavery, states rights, and the tariff became 'bones of contention, the Whig Party gradually grew in power, and out of it came the Republican Party, which elected Abraham Lincoln in 1860. The differences between the interests of the Southern States and those of the Northern States were partly settled by the War of the Rebellion, and since the restoration of the nine 'states which seceded in 1861, there has steadily grown a better understanding of peoples living in different sections of our country. Since the Civil War, the most important phase of the development of our country has been our widespread activities in industry, which have revolutionized manufacturing, agriculture, transportation, and mining. A great machine age has changed our social lives. The power supplied by man's muscle or by that of his domestic animals has been supplemented by steam, electricity, and 7) gasoline. The use of this power aided in the production of great wealth, for manufacturing plants grew in size and were consolidated into larger industries. Trusts were organized; and, because of their tendency to monopolize the industries, the Government found it necessary to attempt legislation. In the larger factories, thousands of laborers were employed, each of whom was engaged in some detailed process of production in which expensive machinery was used. THIS NIGHT Linnie Fisher Robinson - We toiled, beloved, to build a universe secure, Hoping for lasting peace, where we could turn To things of home; nor dreamed our sons should thus endure Days like those other ones we knew. But hate fires burn, Raging across the world; dreams fall apart Leaving but blackened ruins smoldering behind, Bringing despair to try the human heart And tear security from out the human mind. Yet counting all the sands our lives have known, Adding our joy when peace lay on the land, We can but say that life is good; we can but own That, through those storms, we knew that God was in command. Today, that candle, in this dark, shines bright For things our sons shall gather past the night!  Psychological WarfareAn Invisible Weapon Mark K. Allen Psychologist, Utah State Training School WAR is fought today from three principal approaches: the economic, the military, and the psychological. Economic warfare means "starvation for our enemies and food for our friends." It means keeping the enemy from obtaining from anywhere in the world the things he needs to live and to make war on usthe food, the iron, the fuel, and the other materials needed to make and operate a war machine. In an age of mechanization, this type of warfare is very important. In this type of warfare the economicthe Allies had the better of the argument in World War 1. But in this war, the Axis has already reduced through conquest this economic inequality. In the military phase of war, until recently, the Axis seems to have had a definite advantage, because of longer preparation, more thorough training, and a more definite military plan than was the case with the United Nations. Our present mobilization and arms production program, as well as mass air attacks on Axis war industries, are calculated to remove this advantage. The third type of warfarethe psychologicalmeans weakening the opponent through all sorts of tricks designed to confuse, to frighten, to discourage, to mislead, and to divide. It is "an offensive war waged with intellectual and emotional weapons to destroy the power of morale resistance in the enemy's army and civilian population and to diminish enemy prestige in the eyes of the neutrals." An Axis spokesman has said, speaking of psychological warfare, that "It is essential to attack the enemy nation in its weak spots, to undermine and break down its resistance, and to convince it that it is being deceived, misled, and. Brought to destruction by its own government. 'Thus the people will lose confidence in the justice of its cause so that the political opposition in those nations will raise its head and become a more powerful trouble-maker. The enemy nation's originally solid, powerful, and well-knit fabric must be gradually disintegrated, broken down, rotted, so that it falls apart like a fungus treaded upon in a forest." Psychological warfare consists of spreading rumors, false reports, threats, and fears of deadly secret weapons. The channels through which this type of warfare is prosecuted are short-wave radio, fifth column, and rumors planted by agents of the opponents and spread by people uncritically. The type of material spread usually has to do with the strength of the aggressor, the weakness of the defender, and the futility of resistance. An attempt is made to discredit the leaders of the opposing nations. In early stages of psychological warfare, a feeling of Page 23 easy complacency is encouraged by promises of non-aggression. Psychological warfare is referred to today by news commentators as the "war of nerves," the "strategy of terror," "breaking down the home front," "demoralizing the enemy," and the "war of words," or propaganda. With the stepping up of communications, especially the radio, psychological warfare has taken on a new significance in the present war. There is nothing incomprehensible in this type of warfare, and every American should thoroughly understand it and realize how treacherously it can attack, even over many thousands of miles of land and sea. Let us, then, turn to the problem of psychological warfare as practiced against the Democracies, Freedom of ptess, of speech, and of assembly all censored or denied in totalitarian countries as a step in the psychological preparation of their own peoplein democratic countries provide fertile soil in which to wage psychological warfare. The Axis program has three principal aims: (1) to increase conflict and disunity among us; (2) to produce anxiety, fear, and confusion; and (3) to produce apathy and disillusionment. Just as the Axis strategy on the battlefield is to divide and then to conquer, so on the psychological front every possible device is employed to promote disunity among us. The starting points are our own latent prejudices. A few of the most common possibilities are racial, religious, political, national, and economic class prejudices. The efforts of the enemies of this country to stir up racial hatreds are well known, and the nearer their claims fit our prejudices, the more they stir up strife and disunity among us. Religious prejudices are easily aroused by propaganda, and political disunity is readily promoted. Repeated attempts have been made to drive wedges between the United States and Great Britain by saying that "Britain always gets someone else to pull her chestnuts out of the fire." Likewise, Japan points out to China the futility of expecting continued help from allies who have so miserably "let her down in the past." Short-wave radio propaganda from nations at war with us has been particularly directed toward stirring up economic class hatred in America. One of the corner stones of this plan of conquest is the hope that America will collapse from within because of the failure to achieve class unity. Labor is stirred up against capital, and capital against labor. Unfortunately, many people in this country are caught in this trap because of already established prejudices along this line of thinking, which, of course, invites propaganda of this character from the enemies of this country. The second general aim of psychological warfare, after divisions are fostered among the people, is to produce anxiety, fear, and confusion. This is done through pointing out to the victim the invincibility of the aggressor. It consists of a strong military power intimidating a weaker one into submission. The weak are told of the fate of other victims, and are warned of a worse fate, and impressed with the futility of resistance. This "strategy of terror' has been one of the cruelest weapons of the aggressors. If weak peoples still resisted after due warning, their fate  PSYCOLOGICAL WARFARE was as bad as promised and became a warning to the next victim. Terror is spread by several devices. Civilian bombing is perhaps the most dreadful. Bombs are even made to scream to add to the terror. Incendiaries and delayed-action bombs prolong and intensify the terror of mass raids. The threat of gas bombs has also been used to advantage. Fear has been spread by such tricks as throwing images on the clouds with huge lantern-slide projectors. _ Little does a warring nation care whether its opponents are destroyed by bombs and shells or by psychological methods so long as they cease resistance. Panic and a broken will to resist through actual combat or war work is the aim of the "strategy of terror." If psychological victories can be won, they are usually much less costly than actual military conquests. It is difficult to estimate how much aggressor armies and machines have been spared by psychological victories of the propaganda bureaus. Confusion is spread by circulating all sorts of false news reports. Reports from an opposing nation may say an attack will be made at a certain time at a certain place. Then the place will be changed. When sufficient confusion has been caused, an attack will be made at a wholly unexpected place. Confusion makes organized resistance more difficult. False reports have been circulated repeatedly in this war by nations whose armies were locked in close combat with those of other nations, often successfully dispersing and disorganizing the opposing forces. The third aim of psychological warfare is to promote apathy and disillusionment. The Axis nations have 25 been known to spread much propaganda about some great action, such as the move through the Balkans, then the talk would subside, then it would start up again and die down again. Finally, when everyone had become apathetic about it, they would strike. Japan talked of arbitrating her difficulties with United States up until the very day the attack was made on Pearl Harbor. The Japanese have repeatedly tried to disillusion the people of the United States about the reliability of the reports given them from the Navy as to losses. Japan's technique is to announcesometimes accurately, but often notUnited States' naval losses several days in advance of the Navy's reports. In the battle of Java, 'in which United States losses were severe, Japan announced them with some accuracy many days before our reportthe aim being to make it appear to the people of this country that Japan forced the Navy to make admissions it otherwise would not have made. People should constantly be on guard against this trick, remembering how important it. Is for our Navy to avoid giving information to opposing nations. Another plan is to announce several days in advance the capture of a certain city which is quite sure to be taken later. This forces a denial from the defenders at first, but an admission later when the city is actually takenall of which, it is hoped, will establish confidence in the reliability of reports from the opposing nations and a distrust of reports of one's own nation. Another trick of similar character, practiced by the Axis, is the announcement of false victories for the Democracies. Since we are watchful for good news, we may accept these reports, not suspecting their origin. Later, when reports prove untrue, we become disillusioned and confused. The secretive way in which the Axis powers plan campaigns often lulls us into a sense of false security. Our perilous plight of unpreparedness during the early months of this war was our punishment for years of this weakness. Nations at war with the United States have taken great advantage of our easy optimism and uncritical self-sufficiency. We have failed to take a proper measure of those who are against us, and we have considerably overestimated the security we have in extensive but undeveloped material resources and manpower. Nations opposing this country still feign weakness at times to lull us into this sense of false security and the resulting relaxation of effort. Another potent psychological weapon is the peace offensive. Should the United Nations appear to be really about to win the war, a strong bid for peace can surely be expected from the Axis. The hope will be to lull the Democracies back into a sense of false security, while further preparation may be made to attack them. The Axis nations real- 2 ize how "pacifistic" at heart we are, and they are sure to attempt to turn this fine ideal to our destruction. The defense against psychological warfare is as complicated as war itself. Let us hope that some understanding of what it is will aid in our resistance to it. However, civilians can prepare themselves against it in some measure by abiding by the following suggestions: First, keep reliably informed on the daily news. Learn to check habitually the sources of all reports and to evaluate their content according to their source. Second, don't carry rumors. They are the most unreliable source of news there is. Remember, most of them are planted by those opposed to us, and they are meant to confuse and mislead us. Always ask the tumor monger where he got his story. Write it down if it sounds vicious enough, then check it with your civilian defense authorities. You might thus help to find fifth columnists. Don't repeat rumors to your neighbots. Third, speak constructively of democracy and its leaders. This doesn't mean not to criticize, but it does mean to learn to see and to speak of all that is good as well as that which needs correcting. FAITH AND COURAGE The following Christmas message by Nicholas Murray Butler may appropriately be carried into the new year: Christmas Day in this year of grace will be celebrated with civilization at the lowest mark in the history of modern times. This means that more than ever men of light and leading and insight must have faith and courage and hope. They must not and cannot let their faith weaken in those everlasting ideals which must rule any civilized and peaceful world....

entries.title: Little Stones that Change the Course of Rivers
entries.author: Lella M. Hoggan

loose_match.content: Little Stones that Change the Course of Rivers Lella Marler Hoggan O river runs down to the sea N without meeting with obstacles and interferences. And no life fulfills its destiny without overcoming trials and hardships. Yet we chafe under restraint. We resent interference. We become frustrated when sorrow and disappointment disrupt our plans. We feel that life should run smoothly for us. Why should our course be hampered and blocked at every turn? Why should obstacles be forever retarding our progress? Are the very fates discriminating against us? Know this, O friend, neither life nor law discriminate against anyone. We reach the high goals we set out to achieve through the conquest of difficulties. Said J. G. Holland: f We rise by the things that are 'neath our feet; By what we have mastered of good and gain. By the pride deposed and the passion slain, And the vanquished ills that we hourly meet. There is a native in his island home who believes that "the strength and valor of the enemy he kills passes into himself." Symbolically, this is true. We gain strength and development from the conquest of difficult undertakings. Disappointments and delays are often the forces that are preparing. Us to assume responsibilities of importance. We have to meet and overcome trials before we are in readiness to accept the great trusts. Said a great poet: A chance rock in an upland brook, May change a river's course. And yet no rock, No, nor the baffling mountains of the world, Can hold it from its destiny, the sea. Though a stone may divert the stream from its original channel, the water flows around it and makes its way in and out, under and over, past stick arid pebble and deadwood and growing things, on and on until it reaches the surging sea. The picturesque cataract that breaks in sparkling grandeur over a jagged cliff and spills itself in lacy rainbows down a mountain gorge, has gathered the very force that glorifies it from the obstruction that blocked its way. To accept the barriers on life's pathway as impediments to progress is to admit defeat before we have undertaken the journey. All lives are beset by struggle and pain and sorrow. This is nature's way of teaching us the things we need to know. We can't gain experience through the efforts of someone else. Our joys and sorrows must come first hand. We have to work in order to learn to work. We have to suffer in order to gain insight into life. We have to pray in order to learn what prayer means. Real values come only through earnest effort. Intellectual growth and spiritual development are not attained. By listless wishing. Emerson said: "The law of nature is, Do the thing, and you shall have the Page 27 power: but they who do not the thing have not the power." It is not the reward, but the struggle that perfects us. Effort precedes efficiency, and "joy is in the quest." Weare forever consoling ourselves with alibis and excuses for the things we have failed to accomplish. Though we can not explain our weaknesses and failures away, even to ourselves, still we can overcome them and lift ourselves nearer to the ideal that we secretly cherish. Our strength of character is measured by our mastery of the trials we have met. What we think and feel and do puts its mark upon us with indelible fingers. Truly "the gods we worship write their names on our faces." SCOUTMASTER and some members of his troop were attending a rodeo. They stood on the sidelines one morning and watched a procession march gaily down the street. Decked in full regalia, a group of Indians from a nearby reservation headed the parade. Brilliant Navajo blankets covered their horses' backs in lieu of saddles. But nothing 'excited the admiration of the on-lookers so much as the gorgeous war bonnets worn by the old Indian chieftains. These bonnets not only encircled their faces with bright feathers and other trophies, but also extended gracefully down their backs nearly to their feet. At the close of the parade a pompous young man stepped up to one of the Indians and offered him a handful of small coins for his war bonnet. The Indian silently shook his head. "Doesn't he understand the fellow?" asked one of the scouts. "Yes," said the scoutmaster, that Indian speaks English as fluently as you or I do. But his war bonnet, like your merit badges, is not for sale. Every eagle feather, every weasel tail, every bear's claw in his bonnet is a symbol of some heroic accomplishment or brave deed. The headdress represents years of effort and is a mark of honor and heroism. He would no more sell it than a king would sell his crown." The scouts understood, for each of them was wearing trophies that had cost him long hours of study and effort to obtain. They knew the delight that comes from a worthy achievement. Too often we adults miss the joy of some great accomplishment because we lack the courage or confi-. Dence to begin. We tell ourselves that we are too old or too busy or that we haven't the ability for such an undertaking. We let our fears and misgivings baffle us. We wall ourselves out from privileges we might enjoy. We permit lost opportunities to taunt us, old age to frighten us, ignorance to threaten us. Our mistakes rise up before us like shrouded ghosts in the darkness to accuse and intimidate us. Down with the wall! Banish the spectre! Forget the failures of yesterday! Are we not God's children all? And have we not been assured that He will give us strength and courage according to our need? To the valiant hearted there is no ultimate defeat. There is always a tomorrow. "True art," says Annie Pike Greenwood, "is in bringing some sort of triumph out of pain.""* Even the Master knew Gethsemane and the cross. But did He not tise to triumphant glory, to stand as the Savior of the world and as a guiding light to mankind forevermore? *Used by special permission of author.

Woman's Sphere Ramona W. Cannon WITH time, woman's sphere has expanded from the primitive dugout to the whole intelligent universe. In today's world, woman is laborer, mechanic, soldier, doctor, lawyer, scientist, statesman, nurse, teacher, philosopher, poet. Never has she had such power to shape the destiny of men and of nations. God grant she may use her strength wisely and kindly and justly in helping to rebuild the shattered world! RENSELAER POLYTECHNIC INSTITUTE, the oldest engineering college in the nation, now for the first timeis adinitting women both to the student body, and to the faculty. IN the University of Southern California two departments are headed by women: the German, by Mrs. Ruth Day, and the Latin by Dr. Ruth Brown. MRS. E. O. HOWARD, "mother" of Salt Lake's beautiful Memory Park, which hallows the memory of the dead heroes of World War I, has lost a grandson in the present conflict. In the former war her only son, a captain in the American forces, died in the Argonne just before the Armistice. His only son, who was born shortly after his father's death, a flyer in the Eagle Squadron, gave his life in this struggle. WENDELL L. WILLKIE reported that Mme, Chiang Kai-shek is the only individual he 'ever met whose personality far exceeds the build-up of press agents. America feels high enthusiasm for the visit Page 34 of this wise, sympathetic Chinese woman who has stood beside her husband in battle and counseled him in his overwhelming difficulties. THE entire personnel of one aircraft factory in Britain is made up of women. MRS. JULIA ELLERTSON ROBINSON, 94, died recently in Salt Lake City. N the American Bundles for Britain campaign, the Red Cross contributions alone have totaled $31,000,000. THE WAACs are to be increased from 25,000 to 150,000. HE spirited young Russian sniper, Lieutenant Lyudmilla Pavlichenko, has captivated American audiences by her intelligence, character, and sincerity. She fights to preserve home and country. She hopes to marry and rear a family after the war. DONNA D. SORENSEN, former counselor in the General Presidency of Relief Society, and a present General Board member, and Leona F. Wintch, General Board member, have each recently given birth to a son. PHILOSOPHY in a New Key: a Study in the Symbolism of Reason, Rite, and Art is a new scientific book of worth and originality by Dr. Suzanne K. Langer of Radcliffe College. One challenging idea in this book is that "man can adapt himself somehow to anything that his imagination can cope with." EDITORIAL Vol. 30 JANUARY, 1943 No. 1

entries.title: A New Heart and a New Spirit
entries.author: Marianne C. Sharp

loose_match.content: A New Heart and a new Spirit CAST away from you all your: transgressions, whereby ye have transgressed; and make you a new heart and a new spirit...." The end of a year is a favorable time to "cast away... Transgressions" and seek to make "a new heart and a new spirit," for there is encouragement in viewing the events of the past year as being behind one and regarding the new year that lies ahead much as a book, unmarred and unmarked, containing three hundred and sixty-five blank pages on which will be written defeats or triumphs, retrogression or progress. It is true that many of the events which may affect one during the coming year arise through no volition of the individual; but the pages of this yearbook will glow with beauty or be drab and even uglynot because of events that may transpire, but according to the manner in which the individual meets these events. The most luminous page may shine with faith developed from experiencing one of life's darkest tragedies. This life is a time of testing and proving whether or not one is a true Latter-day Saint. "I the Lord search the heart, I try the reins, even to give every man according to his ways, and according to the fruit of his doings." To write a yearbook worthy of a Latter-day Saint, one must continually study the Gospel and seek to live a life in accordance with its teachings. The more one studies, the more clearly do one's own faults and even transgressions cry out for correction. In this inward searching, the first examination may well reveal failings manifested in the home in one's daily life. Is there need of more patience and understanding for loved ones, or is there the need for more firmness and discipline? Is a resolution wanted to make every minute count? Brigham Young once said "that our time was all we could call our own, we should have to give an account of it, and therefore we should use it to the best possible advantage in assisting to build up the Kingdom of God on earth." On the other hand, should more time be devoted to the home the better to guard it, should more care be given to train one's children more perfectly in the laws and principles of the Gospel, in having family prayers and in studying the scriptures? One may also resolve to more frequently visit the sick, seek to bring cheer to the afflicted and comfort to the sorrowing, and to more faithfully attend to one's Church duties. But perhaps it is wisdom not to undertake too many resolutions at once, although one does naturally continually strive to improve in many ways. One or two resolutions faithfully kept are better than many abandoned before the keeping has become a habit. It is well, finally, when making a resolution to live and plan for the day alone and let the tomorrows wait until they in turn become today. The present moment is the only time that must be lived. If then as each succeeding year advances, resolutions are made and kept looking toward improvement and development, these resolutions will, in time, serve as stepping stones to a better life; and the yearbooks will glow ever brighter illuminating a character striving to obey that great dictum, "Be ye therefore perfect, even as your Father which is in heaven is perfect."M. C. S.
