Silent Strings Blanche Kendall McKey Second Prize, Relief Society Short Story Contest
WITH more certainty than she had ever felt before, on that late July afternoon, Sheila admitted to herself that she was old. It wasn't because she felt weak or defeated, judging herself as an actor in the life she had led. Rather, it was the realization that she had never been truly herself, and now it was too late. For sixty years she had heard the song of the untouched West with its inscrutable mountains, but she had never tried to sing or paint or write it. She had not used what was finest within her; in fact, she had never been an artist at all. And now she was old. The young Sheila she had beenwith her perky red curls and quizzical blue eyesseemed to stand literally before her faded gaze. She shook herself and crossed to the mirror over her dresser, pressing calloused palms to her creased cheeks, noting the grooves in her forehead and neck. Wind and the open plains had made her fair skin as dry as parchment. Studying the swollen veins of her hands, she saw youthful, tapering fingers reach across the strings of her aunt's harp in Dublin, her aunt who had been a celebrated musician and whose harp Sheila was to have inherited when she became eighteen. But when that birthday had arrived, she had looked across the scorched fields of Zion, to which her parents had fled ten years before, and thought of tapestries and a stately harp whose strings were silent, now that her aunt was dead.
Page 88
"I should have done better," thought Sheila bitterly; "I let little things crowd it all out." She thought of the garden, the children, the endless housework, and of her mother's long illness. "Why did I have such a heritage?" she asked. Then she looked at the picture of Colleen on her table and once more made a solemn resolution: Little Colleen, with the harp of Dublin hidden in her bosom, was going to have a chance to sing. "Are you ready, Aunt Sheila?" It was Elsie's warm voice calling from the kitchen, and thoughts of youth and unfulfilled longings fled. "Yes, I'm ready, my dear," Sheila replied; and tying a white scarf over her thinning gray hair she went out to the shady front porch. The poplars were casting thin shadows across the patch of lawn; the wide stretch of fields was still. Suddenly, from some unseen spot, came the clear call of a meadow lark. Gerald, Elsie's husband, was taking good care of the farm now that John was gone! The front door of the small house beyond the garden opened and John's sister Maggie appeared. She followed slowly the narrow path between the two homes and climbed the steps of the larger dwelling with jerky effort. "Maggie is old," thought Sheila"really old." Elsie came out, crisp and cool in her blue organdy. "Gerald said the rehearsal went fine last night," she said with enthusiasm. "He thinks the pageant's going to be great." "Weel, they'll hae to do some fancy acting if they come up to Sheila'sand that a lang time ago," replied Maggie dryly. Sheila made a gesture of remonstrance, but she looked pleased. "Young folks must have their day, Maggie. And don't you forget that Colleen is going to sing tonight." She squeezed her handbag tight against her breast, for it held Colleen's stirring little note: "I must see you tomorrow, Grandma! I must! I have something important to tell you." Something important! Could it be an offer? Why, Colleen had had only a year of real training. Maggie was describing to patient Elsie the wonders of Sheila's performance in Hazel Kirk. "There, there," cried Sheila with pretended petulance, "let the past be!" But Maggie was bubbling with reminiscences. "Your Uncle John was over-proud of her, Elsie," she said ruefully. "He was sae proud that I sulked. It's nae pleasant for a sister to be shoved aside by a weebit wife." The laugh that had risen in Maggie's throat broke off and ended in a sigh. Both old women thought of John sleeping beside his first wife, the gentle English girl who had not survived the rigors. After a pause Maggie's thin voice rose again. "Your Uncle John was nae the mon to let a bit o' stubborn land get the best o' him, Elsie. He dug out rocks to build his house and brought water down from the mountain for his fields."
BLANCHE KENDALL McKEY
"Uncle John was a thrifty man," corroborated Elsie. "Aye," said Maggie, "and masterful. He had Ireland in his household, but he meant to hold his ain." She screwed her wrinkled face until it gave a distorted impression of roguishness, cast a challenging glance at her sister-in-law, and waited for a sharp retort. But Sheila seemed to be unconscious of the prattle. Elsie noted her melancholy detachment with rising apprehension. Old people were so moody and hard to understand! When they should be gay they sank into the depths. "Come, now, Aunt Sheila," she pleaded. "Tomorrow's the Twenty-fourth! They're putting on this pageant for people like you. Think of all you've done for the town." Her eyes swept the stretches of corn, wheat and alfalfa, the tops of farmhouses in the valley, the paved road which led to the recreation hall where the pageant was to be given. "No one has done more good than you have, Aunt Sheila." Sheila would have liked to talk to the sympathetic Elsie if she had thought the younger woman could understand. In her unhappy condemnation of what she had done with her talents she felt the need of love. That was why Maggie's praise had sounded so sweet. She would gladly have confessed that she felt herself to be a flat failure but for a deep-sunk timidity. Elsie was young and didn't know enough, whereas Maggie was old and knew too much. So she threw them both a Mona Lisa smile and hugged tight the thought of Colleen. Elsie plucked playfully at her aunt's sleeve and shook her bobbed head as though she were still a girl. "No one can go on acting and singing forever," she tactlessly comforted. Sheila smiled again, her glance unlighted; then her lids fell as she caught the significance of Maggie's canny remark: "She's not greetin' for the songs she can sing nae more; she's greetin' for the songs she niver hae sung." Good heavens! Was there nothing that the heart could hide? Such piercing seemed almost immodest. With an effort she lifted her gaze to find Maggie smiling at her fondly. After all Maggie loved her. She felt a painful little clutch at her
89
throat. Then she let her great eyes rest illuminatingly on her sister-in-law's face, fell in with the family dialect and said amicably, "Aye, lass." Elsie ran down the steps impatiently, looking up the road. "Gerald should have been here with the car twenty minutes ago," she exclaimed. "Something has held him upprops, I suppose. It will spoil the whole evening if we have to rush in at the last minute." HALF-HOUR later, seated comfortably in the front row of the balcony which afforded the best view of the stage and so had been reserved for honored guests, Sheila attempted to subdue her rising excitement. Was Colleen nearly ready? Would she have a moment to slip upstairs before the performance? Suddenly she heard a quick step coming down the aisle, and almost before she could turn she heard Colleen's whisper. "Move over, Grandma. I only stay a second." Sheila shuffled. Into the seat reserved for the president of the Relief Society and Colleen slipped down beside her. "Look, Grandma!" 'Timidly she thrust out her hand on which shone the loveliest diamond the old lady  had ever seen. She lifted her eyes to study the girl's face. "It had just come when I wrote the note yesterday. Bob and I are going to be married." "Bob?" wavered Sheila. "Bob Brownell. Surely you tremember Bob." Sheila hadn't thought of Bob Brownell in a long time. With an effort she recalled an apple-cheeked bo "He s been away to medical school, you know, for nearly four years." Colleen's voice trembled a little. She glanced at twotiny wings pinned over her heart. "Bob and I saw a good deal of each other when I was at school last winter." Her hand pressed the small insignia. "Now he's in the Air Corps." Can  SILENT STRINGS Sheila felt a throbbing in her own breast. Little Colleen's hero was offering his life for his country! In a moment the tremulous voice came again. "['m not going back to the Conservatory in the fall, Grandma. I'm going to make bullets. II've got to help." Sheila saw the glisten of heavy tears and felt empty herself. She knew that Colleen wanted to speak further, but couldn't. "Tt's all right, dearest," she whispered close to the wet cheek. "T could never have gone to the Conservatory at all if it hadn't been for your money. And you didn't have any too much yourself. I know that. And you expected so much of me." "It's all right; honestly, it's all right." But Colleen was struggling to make a clearer explanation. "II have to helphelp Bob and the Red Cross and the farmers and everything that means America. You pioneers built such a wonderful country. We wouldn't be worth the dust of the plains if we couldn't protect it. I can't just study music not this year." And Sheila could only reiterate that everything was all right. After Colleen had hurried away, leaving perfume and remembrance of youth behind her, Sheila was doubly thankful that some of Maggie's old cronies had carried her off to sit with them. Absent-mindedly ~ she heard their laughter rise above the babble of talk around her. The balcony became crowded and boys began placing chairs in the aisles on the floor below. The small orchestra 91 filed in. Smiling, the Relief Society president took her seat beside Sheila and became absorbed in her officers sitting on her right. Sheila was grateful beyond expression to be let alone. Little Colleen and her shining diamond! Her courage and faith in America! It was queer the way life surged along. She thought of her years with John. If he had been able to love her as he had loved the wife of his early youth, would that have lessened her sense of unfulfillment? She thought of all she and Maggie and John had given to the land before it had begun to yield. She recalled her mother's privation, felt her horror of famine, and sat as though gripped in the silence of death. And as an accompaniment to the pageant of her mind, she heard the plaintive throbbing of the harp she had renounced. Sheila was so deeply stirred before the curtains parted that the ensuing scenes shook her to her depths. The portrayal of the long trek; handcarts inching through sand; weary voices singing, "And if we die before our journey's through" She scarcely knew what was her own dream, what was acting, and what was reality. Then with a little shock she was conscious of Colleen standing all alone on the dim stage at the foot of a covered wagon. Her auburn hair was demurely parted and arched by a small black bonnet. Her tiny waist was compressed into an unyielding basque. Her skirt, fluted and puffed here and there, fell to the floor. Plain white collars and cuffs softened the severity. Then, without accompaniment, her clear tones filled the hall: O my Father, Thou that dwellest In that high and glorious place, When shall I regain Thy presence, And again behold Thy face? Throughout the four verses she held the audience motionless; she was part of the sleeping encampment, part of the covered wagon, part of the endless plains, and of the still, unresponsive night. And all at once Sheila knew, with the true intuition of a born artist, that her people were too close to their struggles, too young in culture for a great expression. But some day a man or woman would look over the fertile fields of Utah and Idaho and see the land as it was primevally, ringing with the whoop of the Indian, the beat of the buffalo, and the shrill cry of the mountain lion. Or he would look at the imperial mountains and interpret with brush or pen their awful aloofness. It wouldn't be her heart strings aquiver, nor was it likely to be Colleen's. But some day it would come, for a great movement demands a great reproduction, and the message of her hills and plains had never been fitly expressed. And when the painting or play or novel came, her tears would be in it, and her yearning, for she and her parents and John and their friends had made a great work possible. But little Colleen, like Sheila herself, could sing the song of Zion "in a strange land." 'Tears on the girl's rounded cheeks: Then at length, when I've completed All you sent me forth to do   Sheila's questioning eyes were lifted and for a moment she sat breathless. "O God," her heart whispered, "the redemption of man! After all, wasn't that the song of Zion?" She knew that this was true, and knew also that the brush of Michelangelo, the imagination of Milton, and the pealing of an organ in a great cathedral could only suggest the beauty of a soul returned to God. With unconscious dignity shielded by the darkness, Sheila bowed her head. In a moment of realization she was paid for what the years had taken from her. She felt hot drops falling upon her folded hands, but the stabbing regret was gone. SHADOWS Roberta Bates Twilight and the shadows of the stars Fall soft and deep Into the stillness of a murmuring sea; So soon my shadow will have fallen Fallen deep Into the quiet darkness of eternity.  George D. Pyper Milton Bennion Superintendent of the Deseret Sunday School Union, passed away January 16, 1943. Funeral services were held in the Assembly Hall on Temple Square, in Salt Lake City, on January 19. All members of the First Presidency, the majority of the General Authorities, the Sunday School Union Board, and a host of friends and admirers of Superintendent Pyper were in attendance. Brother Pyper had been an xecutive officer of the Sunday School Union Board for more than forty years. He had also served the Church, the state, and the local community in many other capacities. He was endowed with very superior artistic abilities but his artistic interests and attainments in nowise curtailed his business and administrative abilities. This was manifested in his long and successful term, as manager of the Salt Lake Theatre and in his management of numerous pageants, musical and dramatic performances, and publications, many of which he either wrote or edited. (Guaeen D. PYPER, General In his youth and early manhood he served as clerk and later as judge of the Salt Lake City police court. This experience induced him to study law. These studies were, however, interrupted by a call to an extensive missionary tour in the company of Elders B. H. Roberts and Melvin J. Ballard. Numerous subsequent calls by both Church and state to important positions prevented Brother Pyper from resuming his legal studies. ELDER GEORGE D. PYPER To his intimate associates he was best known as a courteous, kind, sympathetic, and understanding friend; he was, indeed, a friend of man. While he was deeply religious, there was in him no trace of the pharisaical attitude so frequently denounced by Jesus. While he attended to all the details of the precepts of the Church, he emphasized the "weightier matters of the law"  justice, kindness, and integrity. His character was, in fact, the embodiment of these virtues. He had ever in mind the greatest of all the commandmentsthe love of God; this he expressed in the love and service of his fellow men. When they were in trouble they came to him for assistance with assurance that this assistance would be given to the limit of his ability. Page 93 To Marry or Not to Marry in Time of War Dr. Harold T. Christensen Brigham Young University MILLIONS of young men and women are asking themselves this question today. In the midst of the uncertainties and the fears of total war, they are wondering what to do about marriage, and for the most part they are confused. The problem is not an easy one and young people are not the only ones who are confused. The many decisions surrounding marriage are difficult enough in normal times, but these difficulties are multiplied and magnified enormously in times of war. War is a crisis in the family institution; patterns of life are changed so fundamentally that courtship and marriage as usual, is simply out of the question. It is hazardous to advise in times like these, for the chance element is great and no one understands very well what the immediate future holds. But hazardous or not, it is important, so that in planning for the future we can be guided by knowledge and understanding as far as is possible rather than by impetuous feelings of recklessness and desperation. The spirit of this article is that of analysis and suggestion rather than preachment or dogmatic pronouncement. 'There is no one formula that will fit all cases and answer all questions regarding war marriage; the decision to marry or not to marry is after all an individual matter depending upon the personal values and external circumstances Page 94 involved in each case. But the decision should nevertheless be an intelligent one, based upon serious thought and a consideration of the factors involved. Our purpose is not to decide the question of war marriage once and for all, but to present some facts and arguments which may aid each person in making his own decision. The Impact of War The repercussions of modern war are felt throughout the entirety of society; no single phase of our social structure, including the relationships of man to woman, escapes. In understanding the problem of marriage in wartime it might be helpful to review briefly some of the effects of the present war upon the family institution: (1) In the first place, marriage, divorce, and birth rates have been greatly accelerated, although it is reasonably certain that this acceleration will be temporary only. Marriages have increased for a number of reasons, running all the way from a desire to escape the draft to either an increased emotionalism brought on by the war, or to a realization that it may be "now or never." Because of recent military regulations, marriage for draft evasion is not as common as it was earlier. Undoubtedly many marriages do take place today, however, due to war hysteria in one form or another. The atmosphere of war is charged with emotionalism; the glamour of the uniform, plus a love for adventure and a feeling of uncertainty in the future, all tend to increase irrational behavior, such as rushing into marriage without adequate thought or preparation. Furthermore, with millions of our boys in the armed services, some of them never to return, there is often the feeling that unless one can marry now he may never have the opportunity later, and hence the tendency to "grasp at straws" in near desperation. It is well known that many women never married following World War I because there were not enough men left to go around (there were more than four million surplus women in the marriageable ages in Germany, France, and England alone), and it is realized that a similar condition will follow this war. In gambling with the future many young men are making sure of the marriage experience before they die, and many young women are saying that if worst comes to worst they would rather be a widow than a spinster anyway. The birthrate has increased as the natural accompaniment of the expanded marriage rate, plus a conscious motivation in some instances, such as draft evasion, the desire on the part of the husband to leave a progeny in case of death, or on the part of the wife to have something to remember her husband by. The divorce rate has increased very likely because more people have more money to finance the divorce proceedings, and also because changes necessitated by the war effort often create family tensions. With millions of men armed services for in the considerable the period of war. Lengths of time, we can logically expect marriage, divorce, and birth rates to fall rapidly in the very near future and to remain low throughout Likewise, with the return of many of these men after the war, it is reasonable to expect a new increase in all of these rates before they again settle down to a somewhat normal level. This was the experience of World War I, and we can expect it again. (2) A second change brought about by the present war is the loosening of moral standards and the lowering of moral conduct. Unfortunately, the rigors and the brutalities of war tend to dull the finer sensitivities of men and, with some at least, to sever the ties binding them to a strict moral course. The normal sex ratio is disturbed in war, placing both males and females of marriageable ages in abnormal environments. 'The male in service is removed from the stabilizing influence of those he knows best and loves, and at the same time is thrown into situations not the most wholesome. The female at home finds courtship competition more difficult because of the shortage of men, and will often lower her standards in order to more successfully compete. And coupled with all this is the hysteria of war mentioned above. Service men are frequently made to feel that loose conduct is expected of them, and girls that it is patriotic to cater to the man in uniform. Many are blindly and selfishly indulging excessively in worldly pleasures on the sad theory that they must have their fun while they can. "Eat, drink, and be merry for tomorrow we may die," they are saying, and as a result TO MARRY OR NOT TO MARRY IN TIME OF WAR 95 morals are given a holiday. It is to avoid temptations such as these that some choose to marry. (3) Another effect of war, and the last that will be discussed here, is the weakening of family bonds and the' consequent growth of family instability. Military life tends to unfit the man for home life after the war; separation of husband and wife for long periods during the war permits misunderstandings and infidelities to creep in, leading toward greater maladjustment later; and when the wife works, she gains a new individualism and financial independence that she may not be willing to yield after the war. The growth of nurseries for the care of children belonging to working mothers, is one noticeable indication of declining family functions in the wartime.
The Pros and Cons of Marriage
No one will argue that all marriages should stop in wartime, and likewise no thinking person will justify all of the marriages that take place under the stimulation of war. Marriage is too important an institution to be sidetracked, even for total war; the future of society demands that it have a position of priority. But marriage in time of war is not only continued, but it is expanded and often perverted as well; hasty unions, ill-planned and artificially lived, are in many cases doomed for failure. The question, then, is not, "Should there be marriage in wartime?" but rather, "Who should marry and when?" And the question is a debatable one. As we have already said, there is no one answer that will fit all cases; each person will need to weigh all factors that are involved in his or her particular case, including personal feelings, but not allowing these alone to sway his judgment; and then with his eyes open he should make his own decision taking his chances with the uncertainties of the day. When such notables as Lewis Browne and David Seabury disagree on the advisability of marriage in wartime, it is evident that the problem is a tough one and that the arguments are not all on one side.* Those who favor war marriages usually do so on the grounds that, even though these carry more risks than do marriages in times of peace, risky marriage is better than no marriage at all. It isn't quite fair, they argue, to expect a young person who has planned his future in terms of family life to forego all of this without a try. Thousands, possibly millions, of young men will never return from the battle front, and, through waiting, an equal number of young women will be left without partners in marriage. Why not enjoy the marriage experience before going away to war, they say, thereby insuring the consummation of love although necessarily gambling on the continuance of the marriage state. In addition to this they point out that marriage tends to stabilize those who enter, giving each something to live for, work for, and die for, if necessary. Contentment and clean living during separation are said to result from the assurance that somewhere there is a husband or wife who cares. Opposed to these arguments are those which make war marriage look
*America's Town Meeting of the Air. "Will War Marriages Work?" Reader's Digest November 1942, pp. 14-18.

like a very risky business. While happy marriage is certainly better than no marriage at all, it is said, unhappy marriage is not, and the probability of unhappiness in war marriages is great. Heightened romanticism and feelings of desperation brought on by the hysteria of war both tend to make marriage a hasty and impetuous affair. In times past girls have asked all sorts of questions concerning their prospective husbands; questions such as, "What family does he come from?" and "How well educated is he?" but now altogether too many are simply saying, "Where is he?" During war neither boys nor girls are as discriminate in choosing a mate as in other times, and they are usually in a bigger hurry to have the marriage performed. All of this means insufficient acquaintance and inadequate preparation for marriage, which in turn means greater marriage failure. Furthermore, long periods of separation between husband and wife, separations which usually follow a hasty wedding and an all too brief married experience, are not conducive to successful marriage adjustment. Worry, misunderstandings, suspicions, and temptations all enter in to frustrate the separated spouses and to make the durability of their union less likely. If neither death nor desertion prevents a reunion of mates following the war there are other casualties that may prove just as bad. If the husband returns home maimed or diseased in some way, for example, the prospect facing a young wife in becoming the caretaker of an invalid for an indefinite future is not a happy one, particularly if the spouses were practically strangers when they married, had little time to get acquainted and become adjusted immediately following marriage, and have grown farther apart through long separations and contradictory experiences. Then too, the dangers regarding infidelity and the cooling or changing of affections toward each other must not be forgotten. Entering marriage impetuously, without preparation, and without the opportunity of normal home life together, make a rather poor combination of circumstances to insure marital happiness, it is argued. And in support of this contention one need only consider the great increase in the divorce rate following every important war.
Factors in Making the Decision
With these arguments in view, and with a knowledge of his own personality traits, feelings, and desires, each young person will make up his own mind as to whether he will marry or not in wartime. But it is hoped that in each case the problem will be intelligently and prayerfully considered before the decision is made, so that the possible consequences of the alternative procedures will be thoughtfully realized and courageously faced. In the spirit of self-analysis the following questions should be asked: (1) Are you well prepared for marriage with each other? If the desire to marry is prompted largely by the war emergency so that you won't "miss out on anything" it is likely that your motives are more those of desperation than of love and companionship. Studies show that marriage is more likely to be successful where the couple has been acquainted for a number of years and has been engaged for a long enough time to adjust and to prepare for what is to come. Unless you have been fairly well acquainted over a considerable length of time, be just a little wary of your motives and also those of your sweetheart. It may be that you are mistaking reckless emotionalism, or military glamour, or mere desperation, for the "real thing." Haste makes for waste even in the marriage game; and it is far better to think first so that "repentence at leisure" will not be necessary. But if you are ready for marriage, and if this readiness has been tested by both time and thought, you may consider it best to accept the hazards of war without letting them change your marital plans. (2) How long will you be able to live together after marriage before the war separates you? The start of any marriage is the most crucial from the standpoint of mutual adjustment in laying foundations for harmonious living, and unless husband and wife can be together for a reasonable period after marriage and under somewhat favorable circumstances they are starting under a handicap. But because of military policy you may not know exactly how long you can be together. In such circumstances the best you can do it to take a chance and do what seems best after other factors are considered. But certainly where you know that you can be together for only a few days, or even a few weeks, you will realize the handicap. Sometimes the wife is permitted to live close to the military camp where her husband is in service, and in this way be with him occasionally. This is often the best solution possible, but even at best it is frequently none too good. High rents, crowded living conditions, frequent movings, and infrequent visits together put them both under strain and make home life difficult if not impossible. (3) Will you be able to finance the marriage? Poverty and economic insecurity are drains on anyone's happiness, even in marriage. This is an important question at any time; but since economic uncertainties are greater in wartime, it becomes all the more important then. With the husband in military service will the wife have adequate financial support? In the event of a child will there be enough to care for them both? (4) Are you willing to accept the inconveniences and the risks involved? If wives are true to their husbands during separation in wartime they will find themselves either staying home or going out without partners, and husbands will similarly find their social life limited. Can you "take it"? Can you be separated and yet maintain the morality and the fidelity required in holy wedlock? Are you strong enough and brave enough to accept the casualties of war should they come to you or yours, and to readjust to whatever the war may leave you? Unless you are mature emotionally, and are brave, the hazards of marriage in wartime may be too great for you. These are serious questions, but they are important for those who are thinking of marriage in this day. Many thousands of the war marriages taking place now are doomed for failure because of the haste and impetuous emotionalism that is bringing them about. But on the other hand, a great many of today's marriages will be happy ones because they were preceded by the thoughtful and prayerful preparation that is ever important, whether in time of war or of peace. By multiplying the uncertainties of the future, war does make marriage more of a risk but it certainly does not preclude the possibility of success. Nonmarriage is better than marriage failure, and if the hazards of war make failure seem imminent in any particular case then that marriage should not be performed. But marriage need not fail, not even in wartime, if preparation has been complete enough and the persons involved are big enough to do their part. That is the answer. Latter-day Saints will let the doctrine of eternal marriage help them solve this all important question. Marriage in wartime should be considered with all the seriousness of purpose as in peacetime, and preparation may be considered as incomplete if the couple is not ready for a temple ceremony. Not even total war justifies a marriage of convenience.

S., "War and the Family," Chapter 24 in Marriage and the Family (edited by Reuben Hill and Howard Becker). D. C. Heath, Boston, 1942, pp. 571-589. Burgess, Ernest W., "The Effect of War on the American Family." The American Journal of Sociology, November 1942, pp. 705-712. Cavan, Ruth Shonle, "Social Crises and the Family: War," Chapter 13 in The Family. Crowell, New York, 1942, pp. 400-425. Christensen, Harold T., "The Family and Mental Health in Wartime." Mental Health, July 1, 1942, pp. 13-16. Gruenberg, Sedonie M. (editor), The Family in a World at War. Harpers, New York, 1942. Palmer, Gretta, "Marriage and War." Ladies' Home Journal, March 1942. The question, then, is not, "Should there be marriage in wartime?" but rather, "Who should marry and when?" And the question is a debatable one. As we have already said, there is no one answer that will fit all cases; each person will need to weigh all factors that are involved in his or her particular case, including personal feelings, but not allowing these alone to sway his judgment; and then with his eyes open he should make his own decision taking his chances with the uncertainties of the day. When such notables as Lewis Browne and David Seabury disagree on the advisability of marriage in wartime, it is evident that the problem is a tough one and that the arguments are not all on one side.* Those who favor war marriages usually do so on the grounds that, even though these carry more risks than do marriages in times of peace, risky marriage is better than no marriage at all. It isn't quite fair, they argue, to expect a young person who has planned his future in terms of family life to forego all of this without a try. Thousands, possibly millions, of young men will never return from the battle front, and, through waiting, an equal number of young women will be left without partners in marriage. Why not enjoy the marriage experience before going away to war, they say, thereby insuring the consummation of love although necessarily gambling on the continuance of the marriage state. In addition to this they point out that marriage tends to stabilize those who enter, giving each something to live for, work for, and die for, if necessary. Contentment and clean living during separation are said to result from the assurance that somewhere there is a husband or wife who cares. Opposed to these arguments are those which make war marriage look
*America's Town Meeting of the Air. "Will War Marriages Work?" Reader's Digest November 1942, pp. 14-18.

like a very risky business. While happy marriage is certainly better than no marriage at all, it is said, unhappy marriage is not, and the probability of unhappiness in war marriages is great. Heightened romanticism and feelings of desperation brought on by the hysteria of war both tend to make marriage a hasty and impetuous affair. In times past girls have asked all sorts of questions concerning their prospective husbands; questions such as, "What family does he come from?" and "How well educated is he?" but now altogether too many are simply saying, "Where is he?" During war neither boys nor girls are as discriminate in choosing a mate as in other times, and they are usually in a bigger hurry to have the marriage performed. All of this means insufficient acquaintance and inadequate preparation for marriage, which in turn means greater marriage failure. Furthermore, long periods of separation between husband and wife, separations which usually follow a hasty wedding and an all too brief married experience, are not conducive to successful marriage adjustment. Worry, misunderstandings, suspicions, and temptations all enter in to frustrate the separated spouses and to make the durability of their union less likely. If neither death nor desertion prevents a reunion of mates following the war there are other casualties that may prove just as bad. If the husband returns home maimed or diseased in some way, for example, the prospect facing a young wife in becoming the caretaker of an invalid for an indefinite future is not a happy one, particularly if the spouses were practically strangers when they married, had little time to get acquainted and become adjusted immediately following marriage, and have grown farther apart through long separations and contradictory experiences. Then too, the dangers regarding infidelity and the cooling or changing of affections toward each other must not be forgotten. Entering marriage impetuously, without preparation, and without the opportunity of normal home life together, make a rather poor combination of circumstances to insure marital happiness, it is argued. And in support of this contention one need only consider the great increase in the divorce rate following every important war.
Factors in Making the Decision
With these arguments in view, and with a knowledge of his own personality traits, feelings, and desires, each young person will make up his own mind as to whether he will marry or not in wartime. But it is hoped that in each case the problem will be intelligently and prayerfully considered before the decision is made, so that the possible consequences of the alternative procedures will be thoughtfully realized and courageously faced. In the spirit of self-analysis the following questions should be asked: (1) Are you well prepared for marriage with each other? If the desire to marry is prompted largely by the war emergency so that you won't "miss out on anything" it is likely that your motives are more those of desperation than of love and companionship. Studies show that marriage is more likely to be successful where the couple has been acquainted for a number of years and has been engaged for a long enough time to adjust and to prepare for what is to come. Unless you have been fairly well acquainted over a considerable length of time, be just a little wary of your motives and also those of your sweetheart. It may be that you are mistaking reckless emotionalism, or military glamour, or mere desperation, for the "real thing." Haste makes for waste even in the marriage game; and it is far better to think first so that "repentence at leisure" will not be necessary. But if you are ready for marriage, and if this readiness has been tested by both time and thought, you may consider it best to accept the hazards of war without letting them change your marital plans. (2) How long will you be able to live together after marriage before the war separates you? The start of any marriage is the most crucial from the standpoint of mutual adjustment in laying foundations for harmonious living, and unless husband and wife can be together for a reasonable period after marriage and under somewhat favorable circumstances they are starting under a handicap. But because of military policy you may not know exactly how long you can be together. In such circumstances the best you can do it to take a chance and do what seems best after other factors are considered. But certainly where you know that you can be together for only a few days, or even a few weeks, you will realize the handicap. Sometimes the wife is permitted to live close to the military camp where her husband is in service, and in this way be with him occasionally. This is often the best solution possible, but even at best it is frequently none too good. High rents, crowded living conditions, frequent movings, and infrequent visits together put them both under strain and make home life difficult if not impossible. (3) Will you be able to finance the marriage? Poverty and economic insecurity are drains on anyone's happiness, even in marriage. This is an important question at any time; but since economic uncertainties are greater in wartime, it becomes all the more important then. With the husband in military service will the wife have adequate financial support? In the event of a child will there be enough to care for them both? (4) Are you willing to accept the inconveniences and the risks involved? If wives are true to their husbands during separation in wartime they will find themselves either staying home or going out without partners, and husbands will similarly find their social life limited. Can you "take it"? Can you be separated and yet maintain the morality and the fidelity required in holy wedlock? Are you strong enough and brave enough to accept the casualties of war should they come to you or yours, and to readjust to whatever the war may leave you? Unless you are mature emotionally, and are brave, the hazards of marriage in wartime may be too great for you. These are serious questions, but they are important for those who are thinking of marriage in this day. Many thousands of the war marriages taking place now are doomed for failure because of the haste and impetuous emotionalism that is bringing them about. But on the other hand, a great many of today's marriages will be happy ones because they were preceded by the thoughtful and prayerful preparation that is ever important, whether in time of war or of peace. By multiplying the uncertainties of the future, war does make marriage more of a risk but it certainly does not preclude the possibility of success. Nonmarriage is better than marriage failure, and if the hazards of war make failure seem imminent in any particular case then that marriage should not be performed. But marriage need not fail, not even in wartime, if preparation has been complete enough and the persons involved are big enough to do their part. That is the answer. Latter-day Saints will let the doctrine of eternal marriage help them solve this all important question. Marriage in wartime should be considered with all the seriousness of purpose as in peacetime, and preparation may be considered as incomplete if the couple is not ready for a temple ceremony. Not even total war justifies a marriage of convenience.

Gardening for Victory Hazel D. Moyle Garden Editor, The Deseret News
To my garden let us raise Daughters of Jove, a song of praise! Orchard of unfailing fruit, Grape and apple, herb and root, Of all the wealth that gardens give Whereby man may eat and live. Here, in fellowship, agree Pleasure and utility.
THUS did the ancient poet Asinius, celebrate in verse the praises of home gardeningand today, almost two thousand years later, gardens again have become important contributors toward the pleasure, safety, and comfort of family and national life. The 1943 home garden will play an important role in our country's mighty program of war, for gardeners too have been called to arms, but our weapons will be the digging fork and the hoe. We must polish off these trusty weapons and prepare to plant as never before; we must make every small bit of earth in our possession produce "all the wealth that gardens give whereby man may eat and live." We must not only raise flowers, but fruits and vegetables as well, for food, we are told, will play a leading part in winning victory. Every row of carrots or tomatoes we can raise and use at our family table will mean just that much more food for our boys on the fighting fronts throughout the world. Our country must produce tremendous quantities of extra food this year to send to our Allies as well as the starving millions of the war ridden earth. And every home gardener must accept the call, and should soon be at
Page 100
work preparing plans for an all out Victory Garden. The home owner who has vacant ground which lies out in full sun and can be reached by water, can make an important contribution toward our victory, for such a piece of land can easily supply fresh vegetables for an entire familynot only the essential potatoes, onions, beets, and carrots, but many other less familiar and equally desirable additions to our daily bill of fare. Vegetables give us one of the finest sources of the all important vitamins, and we must cultivate a taste for new and untried varieties to help add both valuable food and variety to our meals. The owner of the ordinary city lot can also find space for growing vegetables. This was amply demonstrated in Salt Lake City gardens last season when flowers and vegetables were combined, to the enjoyment and gain of many home gardeners. It was plainly demonstrated that there is no need to dig up existing flower gardens, lawns, or shrubberies in order to have vegetables. One enthusiastic garden lover converted a small space at the rear of her home into a combined vegetable and flower garden where she planted rows of vegetables and edged them with annuals, gladioluses and dahlias. Tomatoes and cucumbers were trained on trellises at the rear where they not only made charming backgrounds, but produced fruits of finer flavor, color, and size, than those allowed to grow in the usual mannersprawling on the ground.
GARDENING FOR VICTORY
Currant, raspberry, and blackberry bushes were also planted as shrubs, making handsome foliage plants while at the same time supplying their delicious fruitsnote that each of these does well in shady spots. Almost every garden can find room for growing a few bushes to contribute their fine fruits for the table. Everbearing strawberries were also used in this bounteous garden to give a colorful edging and to provide the owner with this toothsome delicacy from late June until November, while the grapevines that had been set out earlier to make a charming arbor over the entrance to the garden, bore more than a bushel of grapes. Planted two years ago, this small space now produces the year's supply of vegetables for an entire family with some to spare for neighbors and friends, all produced in a space no larger than many that are lying vacant and waste behind the garage on many home properties. Not only does this versatile garden spot give a bounteous crop of eatables, but it also supplies quantities of flowers for all occasions, not to mention the renewed good health and enjoyment derived from its making by its mistress. There are some home gardeners, however, who find no unused spaces for such a venture. Nevertheless, it is quite possible to find room, right among the flower beds, where many kinds of vegetables will thrive. For instance, carrots, beets, lettuce, and parsley make good looking edging plants, and by planting them in front of taller growing flowers in sunny and open parts of the garden, they not only are decorative,
101
but they supply plenty of vitamins. Do not, however, seed your entire spaces at once, but plant a few short rows at a time, then add other plantings at two-week intervals, thus supplying yourself with a constant source of tender young crisp carrots and beets from early summer until late November. Unless the family is a large one, it is best to make small sowings often so that the crop will not all mature at once. Early radishes can be planted right out among the perennials on the very first day of springlong before the unused ground can be dug and prepared for planting. They will thrive and mature very quickly in the well worked and enriched soil of the flower beds, and will be eaten long before the flowers get really started into active growth. Radishes grow to perfection in earliest spring, and successive sowings can be made for several weeks right in the flower beds in any small vacant spots. Last season several city gardeners even boasted of the tender ears of corn that were raised in the sunny open parts of their flower gardens, making bold and handsome background plants, while one Salt Lake City matron won praise and prizes with the tomatoes which she grew among the aristocratic blooms of her rose garden, the two seemed to get along right well together. Green kale was another vegetable which was used to make a decorative planting, but which also proved unusually successful as an added and toothsome green for the dinner table. This bears handsome curly green leaves, and tastes oh, so good when served cooked like spinach or for soups or salads! And several gardeners set out pepper plants, both the green and the vivid red variety, in open sunny spots among the flowers with the best of results. Pole beans were also found to be easily grown and most profitable, furnishing a long season of good eating, and making very good tall plants for the rear. These need a stout stake upon which to climb, while the bush varieties make low bushy plants for any dry sunny corner, and bear fresh pods during the entire summer if kept picked. It should be remembered that all vegetables need and must have sun and plenty of air. Do not expect them to thrive in shady places. Cultivate the soil as soon as each kind germinates, and continue this attention if you wish them to develop well. This not only keeps weeds down, but conserves moisture, and produces excellent crops of high quality flavor. In fact, if you have never enjoyed strictly fresh vegetables, fresh from the garden to the pot, then you have a real thrill in store, for nothing is more delicious eating than really fresh young vegetables. You will find new flavor in every kind you grow. But we must also say a word for flowers, for these too will be important in the Victory Garden. We will need their sweet charms to comfort and bring cheer amid all the turmoil, and yes, perhaps the sorrows of wartime. Nothing has been found that will speak the message of love and courage so eloquently as a flower. We will need our flower gardens in which to work and find the peace and tranquility which is so lacking in the rest of the world. Wartime means little in a flower gardeneach flower goes its own sweet and mysterious way, blooming as punctually and as sweetly as usual no matter how chaotic the world may be. Here alone, all is orderly and calmthe sounds of turmoil only a distant hum. Here, without pang one sees Ranks, conditions and degrees. We must keep up our lawns, even though they are but tiny plots of green, and we must not neglect our shrubs, our flower beds, and our sheltering trees. We will need them as never before to help our morale during these trying times. We must cling to them as part of our way of life. Here is safetypeace and love attend you Here by the lattice along the wall The very trees stretch out green arms, as though they would defend you. "The Garden," Henri de Regnier.

The Road Builder Rita Skousen Miller
When next you look at a beautiful highway, well built, or a vigorous life well lived, think of the builderhis dreams, his labors, and his joy.
THE initials were still there all right. Large and calloused middle-aged hands pulled away some weather-beaten bark, and kind, faded, blue eyes strained to make out the faint, stained letters that he already knew, "W D L," William Dean Lanyon I. Tall pines rose all about him and mountainous growth almost enclosed this little spot. At only one point could he look out and up to the piercing blue sky fringed with reaching pines and down to the rugged canyon and rocky mountainside. There he stood at this moment. It was here beside the great tree that that other Lanyon had stood those many years ago and made his mark upon its trunk. It had been just about this time of yearwhen the worst storms were due and one could feel them coming in the air. The train of saints from Missouri had been anxious to get over the mountain pass and into the Valley. Big Bill Lanyon, the two Minter boys, and three others had spent four days forcing a trail for the covered wagons through the thick underbrush in the bottom of the canyon. Early storms had already covered the trail blazed by the first group of saints through the other pass, and this was their only chance to make the Valley this year. As the signal had gone through for the wagons to start into the canyon, Big Bill Lanyon hadn't gone back but had pulled his horse to the left. After a few yards up the side of the mountain, Big Bill had dismounted and pulled his way slowly up through the timber until he had reached this spot, high and remote and quiet. Then he had thrilled as he suddenly faced the great expanse of bright blue sky with its background of distant threatening clouds against the rough, rugged mountain. As he had looked down he could see the tiny wagons as they labored slowly into view. The low roll of the train and sound of moving cattle came faintly up to him. And the Minter boys were singing again. How the Lord had blessed them! None had known the real tragedy of their situation when the storms to the north had cut them off. All would know when they reached their destination that the Lord had directed them through this pass in time. They had built a good road! Triumphantly it wound and clung to the side of the mountains on the floor of the canyon, and Big Bill's pride excited him as he looked at the thing they had made. With their teams they had fought the big boulders in their way. In fact, the whole journey had been extremely tedious and difficult. Jim Narden was still unable to rise from his wagon and the two little Leland girls were getting worse. There were others. But at last they were nearing their destination! At that moment Big Bill's
Page 103
heart swelled within him in gratitude and there so high above that little moving caravan, for one fleeting moment, he felt close to the heavens. Then he had carved his initials in the trunk of the great tree and with another look had turned and made his way down the steep slope.
EIGHT years later, Big Bill had come back to the great tree with his young son. They had struggled happily up the mountain together and Little Bill had clung to his father's hand as they suddenly came upon the lookout and all that it held. Big Bill had pointed out the dusty road far below. How proud he had been! "To be a road builder, my son," he had said, "is a great task. We must have roadsroads to make life a little easier for our friends and loved ones. Roads to help us accomplish the great responsibilities ahead for us here in this Valleyroads to create a great nation and a great people." Little Bill had listened as he looked at the narrow ribbon. A wagon had appeared and then disappeared again in a film of billowing dust. "You see, son, learn to create things that people can use and enjoy." Then after awhile father and son had laughed and eaten a little lunch under the great tree, and Big Bill had told stories until the sun had set behind the great mountain. William Dean Lanyon I was gone now but here was another Big Bill, a Big Bill that remembered a day spent on this spot many years ago. And the initials were still there. Not as clear by any means but still there, like the words that had been spoken that day. Big Bill looked down into the still rugged canyon. There it wasfinished at last. Its wide expanse wound triumphantly around the mountainside like a beautiful, smooth, satin ribbon. This Big Bill, too, had battled the mountain, blasting solid rock day after day to make way for the steam shovels and trucks. Gradually, great crags and boulders and the loose, touchy mountainside had been first broken, then supported, and then subdued, until now a magnificent highway layquiet and ready and something he had made, but not alone. Beneath the perfect, smooth surface lay a rough little road created with teams and hand picks and another's dreams. Big Bill had not forgotten, nor would he. At the remembrance the scene grew misty, and in his imagination he could almost hear the low rumble of wagon wheels; but then he looked again, coming into view was a train of huge trucks, earth-green United States Army trucks and they carried supplies. The procession was perfect and orderly. Curling Yes, we must have roadsroads to keep a great nation and a great people, roads to make life possible for our friends and loved ones, roads to help us accomplish the great responsibilities ahead of us here in this nation. Then Bill thought of his four sonshappily. They were building roads, beautiful, brilliant ones. One was building his in the sky, another in the sphere of government, another on the sea, another in the mission field. How the Lord had blessed

THE ROAD BUILDER
him! His heart swelled in gratitude and high above the floor of the canyon for one fleeting moment Big Bill felt close to the heavens. Even as he had used the trail, oh might his sons use this lovely almost living thing far below him, and all that he and the Church had taught them to

build a greater way to a better world and a kinder one! Large and calloused middle-aged hands pulled away some of the weather-beaten bark and this very day, if you can find the spot and look closely, you will see the initials of two great men carved together. How Grownup Are You In Your Attitude Toward the War? Mark K. Allen, Psychologist, Utah State Training School
THE great reservoir of human nervous energy within us, is, of all the vast resources of our nation, undoubtedly the most precious. Unfortunately, it is often the most carelessly squandered unwittingly. What are some of the common ways we waste this energy? How do our opponents attempt to dissipate this precious resource? How can we preserve it best for the national good? Most adults, though they have reached mature stature, have not put away all childish attitudes. These immature attitudes carried into adult life waste vital nervous energy. Because a temper tantrum in a child is wasteful of his nervous energy, and that of others, we try to teach him the more efficient habit of cooperation with others. The difficulties almost everyone experiences in adjusting socially under relatively normal conditions are a measure of his emotional maturity. Under the severe stress of the war emergency, all of one's inefficient wayshis personality maladjustments or childish attitudesbecome more apparent. Bad dispositions may become worse under stress; an unhappy marriage adjustment may grow intolerable; the poor homemaker may come upon even harder days. All of our childish tendenciesblaming others, grumbling over inconveniences, for exampleshow up in our general inadequacy to make a happy and wholesome adjustment to the emergency. We pointed out in a previous ar-
Page 106
ticle how enemy propaganda is calculated to waste our energies through creating fears, confusion, and class feelings among ourselves. Fears and confusion which smolder but do not lead to positive action are extremely wasteful of our energies. Bombings and destruction are aimed at wasting the energies of the people, as well as material resources. Think of the man-hours of labor wasted through the time and worry spent by workers in air raid shelters alone. Blockade and destruction of food supplies is another vicious weapon aimed at wasting energy through hunger and malnutrition. Fears flourish more rapidly in the presence of fatigue and hunger. So our opponents hope for us to waste our reservoir of nervous energy through fear, confusion, class hatred, fatigue, and malnutrition. Our opponents have made no secret of their hope and belief that the American people will not endure the hardships of war. They do not doubt that we have tremendous natural resources, but they do doubt our willingness to revise quickly our indulgent habits. Japanese leaders have spoken pointedly of the "spoiled child" mentality of the Americans, claiming that good living has made us soft. It was no accident that cutting off almost all of the rubber supplies we enjoyed was one of the first objects of the Japanese military campaign. We are just beginning to realize the sacrifice that stratagem requires of all of us. Japan is confident we "can't take it" without wasting our energies through whining and resentment. Of course, our task today is to show how badly our opponents have misjudged the ability of the average American to adapt to his difficulties.
HOW GROWNUP ARE YOU?
There are many special conditions incident to our war effort which will cause further waste in our energies. These conditions affect all of us in varying degrees today, and they are likely to become more serious as the war continues. They challenge the emotional maturity of all of us. First, there are innumerable inconveniences and annoyances which interfere with our habitual way of living. There are many shortages of goods that are more annoying than directly vital to existence: sugar, metal goods of all kinds, silk, and especially rubber and transportation facilities. The nervous exhaustion over these small matters is often more than over major affairs, Adolph Myers, eminent psychiatrist, tells us. How sensibly we adapt to these matters is a good indication of how grownup we are. Our government's relation to us in these regulations is like that of parents to their children in matters of everyday discipline. But since we as adults are so accustomed to not being strictly regulated, we have some painful habit revision to undergo. These annoyances call upon us for a mature and patient forbearance. The plumber fails us, resulting in all degrees of serious consequences; the clerks at the stores are inexperienced; deliveries to our homes are rapidly becoming unavailable at a time when we can drive our automobiles to only a very limited extent.
107
The telephone service for civilians is greatly reduced in efficiency, domestic help is almost unobtainable. Tradesmen of all kinds are becoming very independent in serving us. Many of the consumer goods we are able to buy are of inferior quality. All of these daily annoyances add up to a considerable waste of one's vital energies, if we permit them toas our opponents hope we will. Most of us can find a simple salvation from these annoyances and shortages by remembering that "misery loves company." When all women must wear hose not so sheer and lovely, perhaps no one will feel so badly. Business failure in a depression is not so painful as during prosperity, because we have plenty of company in our misery. Already we humorously measure social status, not by noting how new one's automobile is, but by looking at one's tires to see how many miles he still can go. The pain of minor deprivations is largely social. When we are all affected more or less alike, we may even see something amusing in the struggle of millions of people over their little misfortunes. Then there are the shortages just apparent on the horizon which are a more serious foreboding. Some essential foods are becoming dangerously scarce; and while we in America are not seriously threatened with famine, we may undergo some genuine hardships before many months. Meat and dairy products are already threatened. Fuel shortages already have many a household shivering. The acute housing shortage in defense areas is definitely more serious than the annoyances mentioned above. Limited medical and hospital facilities are already entering the acute stage in some rural and "boom" communities. These conditions may necessitate severe sacrifices and much mature resourcefulness in adjusting to them. Malnutrition from actual shortages has not affected us seriously so far. But one wonders how much systematic undernourishment of workers and children is resulting from both parents working, and the general disorder of family life from many causes. Added to the strain of work in many cases is the strain of much time spent in traveling to and from work. All of the energy output should be carefully calculated to determine whether one is utilizing his energies in the best possible manner. In many ways our disorganized way of living today draws heavily upon our nervous energies. The adjustments we must make to a variety of new conditions, from being separated from our loved ones in service to learning a new skill and adapting to a new job, draw heavily on our energy reserves in imperceptible ways. Our children are also making adjustments to new neighbors among whom we move or who move among us. Workers of all kinds from farmers to teachers are confronted with difficult new conditions. Newly increased income itself brings new problems of budgeting. By some of us, foolish spending is indulged in even beyond the excessive incomes. Then follows a succession of worries about meeting obligations. Many people are learning that large incomes bring headaches as well as joys. The problems of any member of a family draw to some extent upon the energies of the others, but so are the new joys shared in a similar manner. And there are many compensating experiences in the present emergency. Some people are for the first time in their lives feeling useful in a great cause. For the first time in many years, they are getting out of debt. Many are now enjoying a more bounteous living than ever before. For some, this new sense of mastery is an invitation to dissipative living, which is usually most wasteful of one's energy reserves. Others are soberly conserving themselves and their substance for living in the better world they believe will dawn tomorrow.
FROM all we have said of the new conditions of today which draw heavily upon our nervous energies, what are some of the common immature adjustments adults are liable to make? We may resort to the device of projecting our annoyances upon some convenient scapegoat. Usually an adult's loved ones in the home are the most convenient objects. Fatigued as a parent often is, he or she often fails to discern the true sources of his annoyances. But the family may not be especially receptive to the bad humor of any of its members, considering their own special annoyances these days. It is childish, needless to say, for an adult to victimize others when he is annoyed or tired. Another immature reaction is for parents to refuse to safeguard their own health and welfare. Fathers and mothers, like their children, often refuse to be governed by ordinary good judgment about proper nourishment, rest, and change.

HOW GROWNUP ARE YOU?
Blaming the government for causing shortages and confusion by mismanagement is a third kind of reaction. Aside from the question of the validity of these complaints, the question is whether this is a mature and sensible reaction. One's congressman might be able to help out if requested; but our neighbor usually does nothing but become infected with our complaints, which he takes up only because they nurse his annoyances. Evasions and "chiseling" are a fourth kind of immature reaction, often associated with grumbling about the government. The task of regulating the flow of materials to civilians is extremely complicated and has been done in great haste to meet emergencies. Many loopholes can be found by those who look for them. Many people do not realize that this is their war, and the successful management of the materials to win it depends upon the individual patriotism of every Americannot just "the other fellow." Rationing regulations depend for their success on our ability to police ourselves. Grownup Americans comply even when they know "no one is looking." Unfortunately, the people who conform conscientiously to regulations are often penalized for the evasions of others. The "chiselers" are likely to fail to see that their noncompliance to regulations is a cause of great waste of energy through the irritation and resentment aroused in the conscientious. Our opponents count on our being spoiled children when it comes to giving up our liberty to do as we please about these things. A fifth immature reaction to which
109
we may fall victim has to do with our race prejudices. Perhaps there is no reaction more difficult to make in a sensible manner than that toward enemy nationals. Much vital energy is wasted in hating enemy nationals in a way that can accomplish no good purpose. Who, then, is the mature American? In our character sketch, we would say that he is the person who 1. Has a sense of humor which overrides shortages and annoyances and who experiences a deep patriotic emotion in helping win the war through a host of "little things." 2. He works hard for victory at the tasks he can do best; but he doesn't have to be scolded about taking proper nourishment, rest, recreation. 3. He puts his surplus funds into government bonds, rather than wasting them on foolish spending, finally arriving at the short end of installment buying. 4. He has a sense of relative values between overtime and high pay and the welfare of his family his health, and his ultimate productiveness to the war effort. 5. He does not spread resentment to others through complaining about government regulations. He advises his congressman of his well considered criticism. 6. He doesn't take advantage of loopholes in government regulations. He is his own policeman. 7. He believes in the ultimate triumph of democratic ideals and indulges in no hysterical national hatreds which may make national enemies of enemy nationals among us; but he has intelligent patriotism which harnesses hatred and deals death blows where they can defeat the enemy.

Amy Brown Lyman Honored Counselor Marcia K. Howells
NEW and distinct honor has been accorded our beloved president, Amy Brown Lyman. She was selected January 26, 1943, by the Salt Lake City Council of Women to fill a'niche in its Hall of Fame. Only three times in the past ten years has this. Distinguished group chosen a few of their number "whom they delight to honor." They have selected women from the leaders of the community because of outstanding devotion to public welfare and civic betterment. At this time when women are contributing so much to preserve cur way of life and safeguard our homes and country, recognition for achievement is very important. Interesting is the fact that the Salt Lake City Council should honor Amy Brown Lyman at this time, when she is general president of Relief Society, an organization with a century of rich experience as a background and characterized by devoted service to humanity. As president of Relief Society, Sister Lyman is giving inspirational guidance to 115,000 women. In addition to her Church activity, President Lyman is recognized as an authority on social welfare work, She is listed in Who's Who in America, American Women, Women of the West, and Principal Women of America. Standards by which women are selected by the Salt Lake City Council of Women for its Hall of Fame are: outstanding and unselfish service to the community during a great part of life; notable civic service and Page 110 AMY BROWN LYMAN social betterment; and outstanding personality. Before the seven women were chosen, important facts were carefully considered, such as heritage and background, birth, education, civic and business affiliation, patriotic service, and inspirational activities. Six other living women were elected to the Hall of Fame this year, sharing this honor with our president. They are Dr. Maud May Babcock, for many years head of the speech department of the University of Utah; Judge Reva Beck Bosone, nationally recognized for her judicial work; Mrs. R. W. Fisher, Chaplain of the Salt Lake City Council of Women; Mrs. W. S. Core, a teacher of citizenship to the foreign-born; (Continued on page 120) Womans Sphere: Ramona W. Cannon THE United States is to be congratulated upon the character of her women military leaders. Oveta Culp Hobby, WAAC (Women's Army Auxiliary Corps) commander, has. Been a state parliamentarian, lawyer, newspaper executive, bank director, author, and political worker. She is the charming wife of a former governor of Texas, and mother of two children. Dr. Mildred McAfee, lieutenant commander of more than 10,000 WAVE'S (Navy's Women Appointed for Volunteer Emergency Service), was president of Wellesley College, and has been a beloved teacher, church worker, and dean of women. Mrs. Nancy Harkness Love, 28, commander of the WAFS (Women's Auxiliary Ferrying Squadron), has practiced many types of flying, with 1200 hours to her credit. Possibly the 500 or 600 qualifying as WAFS will pilot army bombers into war zones. Lieutenant commander Dorothy Stratton of the SPARS ("Semper paratus'""Always Ready,' Women's Coast Guard Reserve), is also an exceptional woman. Julia Flikke, motherly 63-year-old widow, has directed nurses since she took 100 of them to France in World War I. First American woman to rank as colonel, she now commands 31,000 nurses, some of whom are serving in Iceland, Alaska, England, Australia, Africa, India and the Solomons. IDEAS of notable women on how to win the peace. Queen Wilhelmina of the Netherlands: Nations must conquer their desire for revenge and aim at justice for all. Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt: Women of many nations have earned the tight to representation at the peace table and should be preparing themselves for such responsibility. Dorothy Thompson: United States' genius for production should be directed toward the abolishment of slums, the creation of a network of high grade hospitals that would leave no community unprovided for, and other social betterment. Pearl Buck: We must truly cooperate with the Eastern races, but, in order to do so, we must study and understand them. Helen Keller: We are responsible for other lives, for gentleness, for culture and progress. We must give now of our love and our free spirit, not to nations or peoples, but "just the vast humanity that is being poured out in blood and anguish." We must have equal rights and opportunities for all persons, and breathe the spirit of American democracy more invincibly than our enemies have spread their propaganda of tyranny and viciousness. Page 11 EDITORIAL cm Vol. 30 Our Freedom and Responsibilities IN this month of February 1943, when Americans in every walk of life are struggling valiantly to preserve and protect the American way of life, the birthday anniversaries of two great statesmen, George Washington and Abraham Lincoln, serve to remind us of the heroic struggles of the past that have given us the freedoms and the opportunities which we so jealously defend today, and impress upon us anew our duties and responsibilities toward our Government. Prophets of old declared this continent a land of promisea land of promise because of the fertility of its soil, the extensiveness of its streams, the preciousness of its ores "in which this land... Doth abound most plentifully"; a land of promise because God through his prophets declared it so. The Prophet Lehi said: "Wherefore, this land is consecrated unto him whom He shall bring. And if it so be that they shall serve Him according to the commandments which He hath given, it shall be a land of liberty unto them." The truly great statesmen whose ideals and labors have helped to establish the American way of life, which we so highly prize today, were righteous men, having in their hearts a love for humanity and a sincere desire for the welfare of their brothers. We have only to read the lives of such men as Washington, Lincoln, and others to see that their Page 112 hearts were filled with the desire to promote the freedom and well-being of their fellow men. The spirit of God actuates all men whose desires are righteous and who unselfishly work for the good of mankind. "By means of this spirit, every man is enlightened... Each in accordance with his capacity to receive the light." Inspired by the Father, our early American statesmen gave us the Constitution whereby we enjoy the greatest freedom of any people on earth. The Prophet Joseph Smith referred to the Constitution of the United States as "a glorious standard... Founded in the wisdom of God." The Lord has told us through revelations to the Prophet Joseph Smith that "Governments were instituted of God for the benefit of man; and that He holds men accountable for their acts in relation to them, both in making laws and administering them for the good and safety of Society." Early in the History of the Church the Prophet Joseph Smith declared one of the fundamental tenets of Mormonism to be: "We believe in being subject to kings, rulers, presidents, and magistrates, in obeying, honoring and sustaining the law." The true Latter-day Saint yields obedience to the law because of his firm belief in the eternal fact that a successful society can only be built upon voluntary obedience by all of February 1943 No. 2 EDITORIAL its members to the laws which govern it. The Savior unequivocally endorsed obedience to law when He said: "Render unto Caesar the things which are Caesar's, and unto God the things which are God's." George Washington in his Farewell Address said: "I believe every citizen should support the Government when final action is taken, whether he approves of the action or not." Yet even while yielding obedience to unjust law, it is the duty of everyone to use every lawful means in his power to bring about those changes which will make the laws of the government under which he lives more nearly conform to righteous principles. Fortunate indeed are we who live in this land of freedom where freedom of speech is lawful; where we may openly seek changes which we believe are for the betterment of our nation. Yet always must we remember that great blessings bring great responsibilities, and we must be sensitive to the responsibility 113 which accompanies the blessings of free speech. Let us not mistake liberty for license. From the Articles of Faith we see that obedience to law is not enough; we must also honor and sustain the law. As we obey, honor, and sustain the laws of the land even in the smallest matters, so we become better prepared to live above man-made laws and become fit subjects of the One Righteous King. This is a day when Latter-day Saints would do well to search the Scriptures for the promises made by the Father to this great nation. It is a time when we would do well to familiarize ourselves with the struggles of the past and the contributions of great men who have advanced this nation as a land of liberty. It is a time when we should meditate upon what is required of each individual as a citizen in this land of promise.
